headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Brent, and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Ope
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Brent, and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions]  As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Friday, February 19, 2016, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern today until 11:30 p.m. Eastern on February 26, 2016. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our earnings call this morning. As you are aware, we released fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings results earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in our earnings call this morning. As you are aware, we released fourth quarter and full year 2015 earnings results earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are posted on our website, www.pseg.com, under the Investors section. We also posted a series of slides that detail operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-K for the period ended December 31, 2015 is expected to be filed shortly. I don't go through the full disclaimer statement or the comments we have on the difference between operating earnings and GAAP results, but I do ask that you all read those comments contained in our slides and on our website. The disclaimer statement regards forward-looking statements detailing the number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from forward-looking statements made therein. And although we may elect to update forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if estimates change, unless, of course, required by applicable securities laws. We also provide commentary with regard to the difference between operating earnings and net income reported in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States. PSEG believes that the non-GAAP financial measure of operating earnings provides a consistent and comparable measure of performance to help shareholders understand trends. 
I'm now going to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group, and joining Ralph on the call is Dan Cregg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions. [Operator Instructions]  Thank you.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. This morning, we reported operating earnings for the full year 2015, and I'm pleased to report that it was a year of significant accomplishment. As you saw this morning, we reported operatin
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. This morning, we reported operating earnings for the full year 2015, and I'm pleased to report that it was a year of significant accomplishment. As you saw this morning, we reported operating earnings for the fourth quarter of $0.50 per share versus $0.49 per share earned in the fourth quarter of 2014 despite the unseasonably mild weather this past December. Results for the full year were $2.91 per share or 5% greater than 2014's operating earnings of $2.76 per share. This is at the upper half of our guidance of $2.85 to $2.95 per share, and it was also higher than the midpoint of our original guidance of $2.85 per share. Our souls reflect the benefits of excellent performance and robust organic growth, which offset the impact of low energy prices on earnings. We have continued to successfully deploy our strong free cash flow into customer-oriented investment programs that have supported both. 2015's operating earnings represented the third year of growth in earnings, now let me just mention a few of the year's highlight. 
PSE&G was named Electric Light and Power's Utility of the Year and was named the Most Reliable Utility in the Mid-Atlantic for the 14th consecutive year. But we're not resting on those laurels. PSE&G invested approximately $2.7 billion during 2015 on programs to further enhance the system's resiliency and its reliability. During the year, PSE&G placed into service key backbone transmission lines such as the Susquehanna Road line as well as at the Nicholson Glouster Camden line which are designed to meet the need of customers today and well into the future. PSE&G invested over $550 million on programs under its $1.2 billion Energy Strong initiative. These programs are designed to strengthen and protect the electric and gas distribution systems from the impacts of extreme weather. During the year, PSE&G also received approval from the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to invest an additional $95 million and its award-winning energy efficiency programs and to continue the work under Energy Strong, replacing aging cast iron natural gas pipe. The $905 million Gas System Modernization Program represented the 14th multiyear investment program approved by the BPU since PSE&G's last base rate case, and this speaks to the state's support of infrastructure investment that meets the needs of customer. PSE&G's investment program supported recovery -- revenue recovery mechanisms and tight control of O&M expenses have provided growth in PSE&G's operating earnings of approximately 13% per year for the 5-year period ended 2015. During this period PSE&G's rate base expanded at a rate of 11% per year, and importantly, we have been able to support this growth as customer builds have declined. 
But 2015 was not just a year of PSE&G accomplishment. PSE&G Power's strong operating per supported earnings in line with guidance for the full year despite very difficult market conditions. The nuclear fleet, operated at a capacity factor of greater than 90% for the year and accounted for 54% of the fleet's output. Power's gas-fired combustion turbine fleet set a new record for output. This improves on the prior record established in 2014. The fleet's performance is benefiting from investments that have improved the efficiency, increased its capacity and provided greater access to low-cost gas supplies. The flexibility and diversity of Power's fleet have allowed us to provde approximately $500 million of positive free cash flow in 2015, even during soft energy market conditions. Power also plans to invest $2 billion over the next 3 to 4 years to add approximately 1,800 megawatts of new, efficient combined cycle gas-fired turbine efficiency. That's at turbine capacity. The Keys Energy Station, which is located in Southwestern, will extend Power's footprint in this core PGM footprint. A new efficient unit at the Sewaren in New Jersey will replace old inefficient capacity. And after clearing the most recent capacity auction in New England, Power will construct a new 485-megawatt combined cycle unit at its existing Bridgeport Harbor existing site, giving us unenviable and growing position in both energy and capacity markets in Southwestern Connecticut.  The addition of these units will transform Power's generation mix as its ownership of efficient, reliable gas-fired capacity will grow to exceed 5,000 megawatts in 2019. At that time, the combined cycle gas turbine fleet will surpass the size of Power's ownership and nuclear capacity and secure Power's position as the low-cost generator, with modern, flexible, clean assets that remain capable of meeting the demands for reliability in today's market. 
Power also grew its investment in contracted solar energy. In 2015, Power added 2 projects representing an investment of approximately $75 million in utility scale grid connected solar energy. And earlier this year, Power announced that it will invest an additional $150 million in 3 projects that bring its portfolio of solar projects to 240 megawatts DC of clean renewable energy. All projects in this portfolio are under long-term contracts with credit-worthy customers. So as you can see, we continue to explore opportunities to expand and optimize Power's fleet. Although I will add that we do not see any new generation built in the foreseeable future, although you never say never, but we don't plan any at this point in time. 
Our balance sheet continues to provide us with a competitive advantage to finance our capital program without the need to excess the equity markets. We ended 2015 with strong credit metrics and an extension of bonus depreciation through 2019 and expect it to provide enterprise an additional $1.7 billion of cash during this period. Our investment program calls for 21% increase in capital spending to $11.5 billion for the 3 years ended 2018 from capital invested during the 3-year period ended 2015. Approximately 72% of that amount, or $8.3 billion over this time frame, will be invested by PSE&G on transmission and distribution infrastructure programs that customers will require for reliability. This level of investment is expected to yield growth in PSE&G's rate base for the 3 years ended 2018 of 10% per year, even after taking into account the impact of bonus depreciation on rate base. The remaining approximate 27% or $3.2 billion of expected capital investment will be made at Power. The majority of Power's investments will be devoted to expanding its position in new, efficient, clean gas-fired generating capacities, as mentioned already, all of which, Keys, C1 and Bridgeport Harbor are expected to exceed our long-standing and unchanged financial returns expectations. 
With our strong balance sheet, we remain in the position to increase our capital investment across the company. We have a robust pipeline of opportunities and plan on providing you with an update of our 5 year outlook for capital spending at our annual financial conference on March 11. In total, the investment program in PSE&G and Power are focused on meeting customer needs and market requirements, with an energy platform that is reliable, efficient and clean. The strategy we implemented is yielding growth for our shareholders as we have met the needs of our customers. The continued successful deployment of strong free cash flow and to customer-oriented regulated investment program is expected to support 14% growth in the utility's earnings to 60% of enterprises 2016 operating earnings as the results for the full year are forecast at $2.80 to $3 per share. Our guidance for 2016 takes into account the impact on demand from the continuation of unseasonably mild weather conditions in January and early February. The Board of Directors' recent decision to increase the common dividend by 5.1% to the indicative annual dividend of $1.64 per share is an expression of our confidence in our outlook, the continued growth of our regulated business and an acknowledgment of our strong financial position. We see the potential for consistent and sustainable growth in the dividend as an important means of returning cash to our shareholders. Of course, none of our success would be possible without the contribution made by PSEG's dedicated workforce. 
I look forward to discussing our investment outlook in greater detail with you on our March 11th annual financial conference, but for now, I'll turn the call over to Dan for more details on our operating results and we'll be available to answer your question after his remarks

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the fourth quarter of $0.50 per share versus $0.49 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Earnings in the quarter brought operating earnings for the full
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the fourth quarter of $0.50 per share versus $0.49 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Earnings in the quarter brought operating earnings for the full year to $2.91 per share or 5.4% greater than 2014's operating earnings of $2.76 per share, and at the upper half of our guidance of $2.85 to $2.95 per share.  And on Slide 4, we provide you with a reconciliation of operating earnings to net income for the quarter. 
We've also provided you with information on Slide 10 regarding the contribution to operating earnings by business for the quarter. And Slides 11 and 13 contain waterfall charts that take you through the net changes, quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year changes in operating earnings by major business. And I'll review each company in more detail starting with PSE&G. PSE&G reported operating earnings for the fourth quarter of 2015 of $0.31 per share compared to $0.32 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014, and that's shown on Slide 15. PSE&G's full year 2015 operating earnings were $787 million or $1.55 per share compared with operating earnings of $725 million or $1.43 per share for 2014, reflecting a growth of 8.6%. PSE&G's earnings for the fourth quarter benefited from a return on its expanded capital program, which partially offset the impact of earnings from unseasonably mild weather conditions and an increase in operating expenses. PSE&G's return on unexpanded investment transmission and distribution programs increased quarter-over-quarter earnings by $0.03 per share. Mild weather conditions relative to normal and relative to last year reduced electric sales and lowered earnings comparisons by $0.01 per share. Recovery of gas revenue under the weather normalization clause offset the impact on earnings of abnormally warm weather on sales of gas. And higher expenses, including pension and other items, reduced quarter-over-quarter earnings comparisons by $0.03 per share. 
Economic conditions in the service area continued to improve. On a weather-normalized basis, gas deliveries are estimated to have increased 2.1% in the quarter and 2.2% for the year. Demand continues to benefit from an improving economy, and also from the impact of both commodity prices on customers' bills. Electric sales, on a weather-normalized basis, are estimated to have increased by 0.8% and 0.5% for the fourth quarter and for the year respectively. The estimated year-over-year growth and the electric sales is more representative of our long-term expectations for growth. PSE&G implemented a $146 million increase in Transmission revenue under the company's Transmission formula rate for 2016 on January 1. PSE&G investment in Transmission grew to $5.7 billion at the end of 2015 or 43% of the company's consolidated rate base of $13.4 billion at year-end. As you know, Transmission revenues are adjusted each year to reflect an update of data that was estimated in the Transmission formula rate filing. The adjustment for 2016, which we will file in mid-2017, will include the impact of the extension of bonus depreciation, which was executed after our Transmission formula rate filing. This adjustment will reduce Transmission revenue as filed by about $27 million, but we will accrue that for cutting purposes in anticipation of reduction of revenue as we report our 2016 results.  We are forecasting growth in PSE&G's operating earnings for 2016 to a range of $875 million to $925 million, and the forecast reflects the benefits of continued growth in PSE&G's rate base and a decline in pension expense. 
Turning to Power as shown on Slide 19, Power reported operating earnings for the fourth quarter of $0.19 per share compared to $0.18 per share a year ago. The results for the quarter brought Power's full year operating earnings to $653 million or $1.29 per share compared to 2014's operating earnings of $642 million or $1.27 per share. Power's adjusted EBITDA for the quarter and the year amounted to $235 million and $1.563 billion respectively, which compares to adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2014 of $271 million and adjusted EBITDA for the full year of 2014 of $1.584 billion. The earnings release as well as the earnings slides on Pages 11 and 13 provide you with a detailed analysis on the impact of Power's operating earnings quarter-over-quarter and year-over-year from changes in revenue and cost. And we've also provided more detail on generation for the quarter and for the year on Slides 21 and 22. 
Power's operating earnings in the fourth quarter reflect the impact of strong hedging and tight control on operating expenses, which offset any anticipated decline in capacity revenue and the impact of unseasonably warm weather on wholesale energy prices. A decline in capacity revenue associated with the May 2015 retirement of the high electric demand day, or ATDP peaking capacity in PGM, reduced quarter-over-quarter earning comparisons by $0.04 per share. Increase in the average price received on energy hedges, coupled with a decline in fuel cost, more than offset the impact on earnings from a reduction in gas sales. And these 2 items together netted to a quarter-over-quarter improvement in earnings of $0.02 per share. Power's O&M expense for the quarter was unchanged relative to year ago levels. And increase in depreciation expense and other miscellaneous items was more than offset by the absence of the charge in the year ago quarter resulting in net improvement in quarterly earnings comparisons of $0.03 per share. 
Turning to Power's operations, Power's output during the quarter was in line with year-ago levels. For the year, output increased 2% to 55.2 terawatt hours, and the level of production achieved by the fleet in 2015 represented the second-highest level of output in the fleet's history as a merchant generator. Also, supported the improvement in the fleet's availability and efficiency. The nuclear fleet operator had an average capacity factor of 90.4% for the year, producing 30 terawatt hours or 54% of total generation. Efficient cycle gas turbine capacity was rewarded in the market with an increase in dispatch levels. And Power CCG fleet set a record generation during the year at each of the stage and upping energy center set individual records. Output from the combined cycle fleet grew 11% to 18.4 terawatt hours or 33% of total output during the year. 
Lower market demand for our coal units, reduced output for those stations 5.8 terawatt hours per year or 11% of output. And lastly the fleet's peaking capacity produced just under 1 terawatt hour or 2% of output for the year. Power's gas-fired combined cycle fleet continues to benefit from its access to lower price gas supplies in the Marcellus region and for the year, gas from the Marcellus supplied 70% of the fuel requirements for the PJM gas-fired assets. This supply supports higher support spread than implied by market pricing and allowed Power fuel savings in the fourth quarter similar to the levels it enjoyed in the year-ago quarter despite weak energy prices. And for the full year, Power enjoyed positive spreads relative to the market, a year-over-year realized spreads in 2015 were lower than what was realized in 2014 given the decline in energy prices. 
Overall, Power's gross margin improved slightly to $38.83 per megawatt hour in fourth quarter versus $37.40 per megawatt hour in the year-ago quarter. And for the year, Power's gross margin amounted to $42.25  per megawatt versus $42.41 per megawatt hour last year. And Slide 24 provides detail on Power's gross margins for the quarter and for the year. Power's expecting output for 2016 remains unchanged at 54 to 56 terawatt hours. Following the completion of the Basic Generation Service for BGS auction in New Jersey earlier this month, Power has 100% of its 2016 baseload generation hedged. Approximately 70% to 75% of Power's anticipated total production is hedged on an average price of $51 per megawatt hour, and Power has hedged approximately 45% to 55% of its forecast generation in 2017 of 54 to 56 terawatt hours at an average price of $50 per megawatt hour. 
Looking forward to 2018, Power's forecasting an improvement in output of 59 to 61 terawatt hours with the commercial start up in mid-2018 of the Keys and Sewaren stations that Ralph mentioned earlier. Approximately 15% to 20% of 2018's output is hedged at an average price of $54 per megawatt hour, and Power's BGS volumes will continue to represent approximately 11 to 12 terawatt hours of deliveries. And this number is very consistent with the 11.5 terawatt hours of deliveries we saw in 2015 under the BGS contract. Our average hedge position at this point in time, represents a slightly smaller percentage of hedged versus what you saw a year ago, and at that time, Power is able to take advantage of market prices influenced by the colder than normal weather conditions over last winter. Average hedge pricing includes the impact of recently concluded  BGS auction. And the auction for the 3-year period beginning June 1, 2016 ending May 31, 2019, was priced at $96.38 per megawatt hour in the zone. This contract for 1/3 of the load will replace the 2013 contract for $92.18 per megawatt hour which expires on May 31, 2016. And we do remind you from time to time that there are items included in the average hedge price which influence Power's revenue but don't support Power's gross margin. Our average hedge price for 2016 a $51 per megawatt reflects an increase in the cost of elements such as Transmission and renewables associated with serving our full requirements hedge obligations. Based on our current hedge position for 2016, each $2 change in spark spreads will impact earnings by about $0.04 per share. 
Power's operating earnings for 2016 are forecasted at a range of 490 -- $490 million to $540 million. That forecast includes an adjusted EBITDA of $1.320 billion to $1.4 billion. The forecast reflects a year-over-year decline in capacity revenues associated with the May 2015 retirement of the ATTD peaking capacity. Operating earnings for the year will also be influenced by the recontracting of hedges at lower average price and a decline in gas sales, and most of the decline in Power's operating earnings forecast for the full year 2016 is expected to be experienced in the early part of 2016. With respect to Enterprise and Other, we reported operating earnings in the fourth quarter of $4 million which compares to a loss in operating earnings of $4 million or $0.01 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014, and results for the fourth quarter brought full year 2015 operating earnings to $36 million or $0.07 per share compared with 2014's operating earnings of $33 million or $0.06 per share. The difference in quarter-over-quarter operating earnings reflects the absence of prior year tax adjustments, as well as other parent-related expenses in 2015.  For the year, PSEG Long Island's earnings contributions of $0.02 per share was in line with expectations. And looking forward to 2016, operating earnings for PSEG Enterprise and Other are forecast at $60 million. 
Next, I want to provide an update on our pension. Beginning with 2016, PSEG has elected to measure service and interest cost per pension and other postretirement benefits by applying the specific spot rates along the yield curve to the plan's liability cash flows rather than the prior use of a single weighted average rate. We believe the new approach provides a precise measurement of service and interest cost by aligning the timing of the plan's liability cash flows to the corresponding spot rates on the yield curve. The change does not affect the measurement of the plan obligations, and we estimate this change will reduce 2016 pension and OPEB expense by approximately $34 million and $13 million respectively net of amounts capitalized from what would have been without this change. On a year-over-year basis, the pension expense is expected to decline -- pension and OPEB expense is expected to decline by $25 million from 2015's level of expense. 
We ended 2015 with 91% of our pension obligations funded and minimum need of cash funding of obligations over the next several years. With respect to our financial condition, that remains strong. We closed 2015 with $394 million of cash on hand and debt representing 43% of our consolidated capital position and debt at Power representing 27% of our capital base. PSEG's capital program for the 3 years ended 2018 is currently expected to approximate 11.5 billion. This represents a 21% increase over the level of capital investment over the prior 3-year period as PSE&G can Power focus on modernizing their Infrastructure to meet the needs of today's marketplace. We have ample capacity to finance our current capital program. In addition, we estimate that the change in bonus depreciation, as Ralph mentioned, will provide an additional $1.7 billion of cash through 2019, with most of this cash received under the 3 years ending 2018. And of this amount, $1.2 billion of the cash will be on PSE&G and $500 million will be at Power. And as mentioned, our forecast for double-digit growth in PSE&G's rate base through 2018 does take into account the impact of bonus depreciation on rate base. And we plan to provide an updated 5-year view of capital spending at the annual conference on March 11. 
So regarding to earnings for 2016 of $2.80 to $3 per share in line with our 2015 operating results as forecast growth at PSE&G offsets the impact of lower energy prices on Power's operating earnings. The company remains on solid footing, and we continue to focus on operational excellence, remain disciplined in our approach to investment strategy and maintain our financial strength. Common dividend was recently increased 5.1% to the indicative annual level of $1.64 per share and we believe we can provide shareholders with consistent and sustainable growth in the dividend going forward. 
And with that, we're ready to answer your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. On the change in pension accounting methodology, could you just give -- is this designed to bring you more into line with standard practice or something -- can you give us some perspective around what drove that change?
componenttext: Couple of questions. On the change in pension accounting methodology, could you just give -- is this designed to bring you more into line with standard practice or something -- can you give us some perspective around what drove that change?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it will probably increasingly look more like standard practice. In applying an interest rate we had normally done a weighted average rate, which is across all of the cash flows and some recent determination has been made that in looking at the yie
componenttext: I think it will probably increasingly look more like standard practice. In applying an interest rate we had normally done a weighted average rate, which is across all of the cash flows and some recent determination has been made that in looking at the yield curve and the timing of your actual payments and the timing of the interest by virtue of the shape of the yield curve, a more accurate method was to apply the near term interest rates to the nearer term cash flows and the longer-term interest rates to the longer-term cast grows. So we've been looking at this for a while, and in addition to being a more accurate method, I think you'll start to see this more and more in others.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your sense is the others do not have adopted this yet but do think it will go that way, is it that a good rate?
componenttext: So your sense is the others do not have adopted this yet but do think it will go that way, is it that a good rate?

componenttext: On the second piece, it's about half and half, is a general way to think about it, and with the yield curve that rises over time, you will see a moderation of the benefit of this method over time, but remaining positive based upon all the current assumptions in place through the balance of the 5 year plan period. So it remains positive with declines over time.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to go back a little bit to the latest BGS auction and ask you if you could elaborate a little bit on what exactly drove the year-over-year results, and perhaps at least our perception of a reduction on the risk premium. Can you elaborate kind
componenttext: So I wanted to go back a little bit to the latest BGS auction and ask you if you could elaborate a little bit on what exactly drove the year-over-year results, and perhaps at least our perception of a reduction on the risk premium. Can you elaborate kind of what the dynamics it is you saw?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, some of the bigger pieces, Julien, I think are fairly transparent from what you can see from a market perspective. I think we saw a little bit of a decline in the energy prices, which is kind of where you start as a baseline for the auction.
componenttext: Yes, I mean, some of the bigger pieces, Julien, I think are fairly transparent from what you can see from a market perspective. I think we saw a little bit of a decline in the energy prices, which is kind of where you start as a baseline for the auction. And then probably the couple other areas where you see the biggest change is against that decline as you have seen a bump on the Transmission side and you've seen a bump related to some of the green costs that are involved. So you can track the green costs and the New Jersey SREX and you can track the transmission. I think the BPU even sent out some of the Transmission costs and they ultimately get embedded in. And then finally, the last big piece which is of course fairly transparent is the capacity piece and those auctions take place in advance of by virtue of their 3-year forward market and the BGS forward market takes place in advance of the BGS auction. So those are your biggest movers. And there's other pieces obviously in there, there's ancillary and different components but those are the biggest pieces you see relating to the changes.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But just coming back to -- clearly, some of the big changes are moving year-over-year, but at least from our calculation it seems as if even adjusting to that, there might have been even a little bit less on the premium there, just being curious.
componenttext: But just coming back to -- clearly, some of the big changes are moving year-over-year, but at least from our calculation it seems as if even adjusting to that, there might have been even a little bit less on the premium there, just being curious.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, we don't really talk necessarily about what kind of a premium you would see in a product but I think you can, most of those are transparent enough that you could build out and see what the elements of them are. I think you're seeing a bit of a dec
componenttext: I mean, we don't really talk necessarily about what kind of a premium you would see in a product but I think you can, most of those are transparent enough that you could build out and see what the elements of them are. I think you're seeing a bit of a decline on the energy side and you are using a bit of a roll up coming on the other direction related to both transmission green.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, fair enough. Going back to the last question a bit more about the utility regulatory, how are you thinking about trackers in a post-rate case scenario? As you think about rolling at least the legacy programs and the base rates, et cetera, can you
componenttext: Got it, fair enough. Going back to the last question a bit more about the utility regulatory, how are you thinking about trackers in a post-rate case scenario? As you think about rolling at least the legacy programs and the base rates, et cetera, can you kind of talk perhaps with the subsequent world might look like?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, while we are pleased with the success we've had, Julien, over this past 7 or 8 years with these programs, we have been talking to staff about, in particular, the gas program which clearly has a multi-decade run that would need to do all of the work
componenttext: Sure, while we are pleased with the success we've had, Julien, over this past 7 or 8 years with these programs, we have been talking to staff about, in particular, the gas program which clearly has a multi-decade run that would need to do all of the work that the system requires of it. I'm talking about replacing the cast iron. We'd like to break away from this incremental approach and into more of a long standing approach. If for no other reason that it would be beneficial to develop the infrastructure, primarily people, that will need to sustain these programs, right. So right now, the way we run the programs is we work with contractors and we bring in folks that are needed and we enter into this conversation 6 months before the program expires. But will you need more? Am not sure, we have to wait until basis points ask, when can you find out? I'll get back to you as soon as possible. And that's not the way we typically run a 110-year-old company. We like to have training programs bring people and as an apprentice and has climbed the technical ladder and have a nice, long career, and that's a much more efficient way to use customer rates. So I think that program in particular could be a template for the type of ongoing things we want to do. A close second to that, as you may recall, Energy Strong, we have put forth a 10 year plan that got approved for 3 years, and some of the cleaner technologies, whether it's solar or energy efficiency that will be needed to meet the state's own renewables target portfolio or whatever becomes of CPP and whatever reincarnation it takes. I think all lend themselves to more problematic and long-standing programs that we can anticipate and rationally equip ourselves to execute. So those conversations are going above the board staff now. And to their credit, the response is well, you should have confidence, you, and 14 times and 14 times we said yes, and that's true. So the question is how much of an investment risk are you willing to make an equipment and training programs and people. Yes, it's pretty much assured but has different forms, right. Half the program, half the duration, maybe 3/4 of the run rate. So it's a very constructive dialogue right now to be continued.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta from Citigroup.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question firstly, you guys sit in a very interesting spot. You own all 3 assets, coal, gas and nuclear, and it's interesting the trends you highlight with gas capacity factors increasing, coal reducing. My question is how are you thinking about asset-l
componenttext: My question firstly, you guys sit in a very interesting spot. You own all 3 assets, coal, gas and nuclear, and it's interesting the trends you highlight with gas capacity factors increasing, coal reducing. My question is how are you thinking about asset-light of these 3 classes of assets given the market conditions you see now? And what does that mean in terms of leverage levels that you're comfortable with for the Power business?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one of the things that's equally important is the fuel diversity of our assets is the technology diversity and performance features of our assets. So, obviously, gas, we have some combined cycle gas turbines which once upon a time which are looking mor
componenttext: So one of the things that's equally important is the fuel diversity of our assets is the technology diversity and performance features of our assets. So, obviously, gas, we have some combined cycle gas turbines which once upon a time which are looking more and more like base load. But we also have a pretty robust and healthy peaking fleet. And simply in our coal assets, we have [indiscernible]  which this slide, rightfully described as base load, and Bridgeport stations has become more peaking with Hudson and Mercer having additional flexibility to be able to run on gas. So it's not just a question of fuel diversity, it is what part in the dispatch queue the asset can play and whether its start/stop features and in that respect, our diversity is served as well. Now you probably picked up that we would anticipate retiring the Bridgeport Harbor coal unit in 5 years provided that we are successful at securing the permits for the new 500 minus combined cycle unit at Bridgeport Harbor, which we don't anticipate any difficulties in doing so given the community benefits agreement we achieved with this important stakeholder groups in Bridgeport. And I'll let Dan finish off the leverage of a little bit once again, our base FFO to that expectations are 20% [ph] and we'll give you more details when we see you in March about we will you are well north of that with bonus depreciation. That number has gotten even bigger.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I would add as, obviously, from a credit perspective, Power's FFO to debt are well, well above the 30% threshold that we have with a rating agencies to hold our existing rating. So that's not something that we have concern about at all. We
componenttext: The only thing I would add as, obviously, from a credit perspective, Power's FFO to debt are well, well above the 30% threshold that we have with a rating agencies to hold our existing rating. So that's not something that we have concern about at all. We have an awful lot of financial strength there. But I think as you do look forward, we will see a shift in fleet and maybe that's kind of what your question is getting at. We got 3 new efficient combined cycle plants, and if you look backwards, I said in some of my remarks that we have some of our HAAD units, those were older peaking units that were retired from environmental purposes and they are going to be replaced by new, efficient combined cycle clean gas units. So the fleet really will take on a different look into the future and will be more efficient and we'll have a better profile and be more competitive [indiscernible]

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. As we see the fleet profile changing, have you seen levels kind of match that in terms of the quality of their new gas fleet that you're kind of bringing on?
componenttext: Got it. As we see the fleet profile changing, have you seen levels kind of match that in terms of the quality of their new gas fleet that you're kind of bringing on?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we'll see some leverage, increase coverage of the spend that will happen. I think we will remain above from where we need to in an operating agency perspective, that capacity at Power is actually strong and expected to remain that way. And bonus d
componenttext: I think we'll see some leverage, increase coverage of the spend that will happen. I think we will remain above from where we need to in an operating agency perspective, that capacity at Power is actually strong and expected to remain that way. And bonus depreciation helps on that side. We have on the Power's at of the we have the benefits of the bonus depreciation of any rate base reduction.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it, secondly, as a more philosophical question. As you think about the fit of Power with the consolidated business, is there, at any point of view that this business needs to be a stand-alone entity or do kind of see this more as part of the consolida
componenttext: Got it, secondly, as a more philosophical question. As you think about the fit of Power with the consolidated business, is there, at any point of view that this business needs to be a stand-alone entity or do kind of see this more as part of the consolidated business in the next 2, 3-year time frame as well?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as I've said before, I do see over time, you're not going to get me to pick a time frame, no. I see these businesses separating. The strategic flexibility of both will be enhanced by doing that. Some of the tactical benefits that's keeping them to
componenttext: Yes, so as I've said before, I do see over time, you're not going to get me to pick a time frame, no. I see these businesses separating. The strategic flexibility of both will be enhanced by doing that. Some of the tactical benefits that's keeping them together right now, which is the financial synergy, the financial complement that Power provides the utility. We've talked about Power's new plants, but for the past 5 years and for the next 5 years, it looks like the utility will be outspending Power almost 3:1 and Power's a great source of equity for that with its funds from operation. Secondly, the complement that Power need to provide on the customer bill is a huge advantage to us. And the support cost synergies that exist between the 2 companies are big advantage to us as well. But as Power grows in New England and as it grows in New York state and in other places, it really to use its own FFO for investment opportunities and that free cash flow that remains help the utility will be decreased. There will be more customers that will be serving outside of the utility's territories, so that complementary nature will decrease. And as they both grow, the corporate overhead, vital functions that corporate provides will be a smaller piece of the overall operating budget. So I think over time, the tactical benefit sustained together decrease and the strategic advantages of separating will increase. But we're not there today,.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's truly helpful. And I know you're not talking timing but I guess the benchmark or at least the milestones that we look for is that those 3 factors in terms of the strategic benefit. Has that, I gues reduces in terms of the [indiscernible] then the p
componenttext: That's truly helpful. And I know you're not talking timing but I guess the benchmark or at least the milestones that we look for is that those 3 factors in terms of the strategic benefit. Has that, I gues reduces in terms of the [indiscernible] then the probability or likelihood of some timing of separation kind of increases, is that a fair way to think of it?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So qualified yes, to that, I mean, there's no magic date. There are a host of parameters one looks at. What are the market dynamics? What's the composition of the shareholder base? Are there other triggering events that could accelerate one's point of vie
componenttext: So qualified yes, to that, I mean, there's no magic date. There are a host of parameters one looks at. What are the market dynamics? What's the composition of the shareholder base? Are there other triggering events that could accelerate one's point of view of where the tactical benefits are now greatly reduced. So I don't mean to be long-winded on it, but you ask a very complicated question albeit wrapped in some shroud of simplicity that the Board of Directors looks at on a regular basis. And so I'm just giving you kind of a general point of view on that. But it's a detailed analysis on a pretty regular basis.

componenttext: Just order of magnitude, there will be a $0.07 next year across the enterprise but there's just a small piece of that, call it $0.01 or so, that is at the Power side of the business where that's coming from.

componenttext: Got it. And can you get a significant margin from things like ancillary revenues or ancillary services and Power IT New England? Just trying to think about the components, not just within BGS but within your broader margin and Power?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have an ancillary number in front of me, Mike, I don't if we break down the fall of the different components of how Power makes money. Far and away the biggest pieces are your capacity margin and your energy margin. There's a host of differen
componenttext: Yes, I don't have an ancillary number in front of me, Mike, I don't if we break down the fall of the different components of how Power makes money. Far and away the biggest pieces are your capacity margin and your energy margin. There's a host of different elements that we work our way through as we manage a portfolio as a whole. I mean if you're kind of talking somewhere in the bucket of $0.05 share or something like that on the ancillaries, that's probably an order of magnitude number. But we haven't broken out a lot of the pieces beyond the biggest pieces, which I think gets folks most of the way home. If you look at your capacity margin, we're very transparent about that math and provide that with an Investor Relations that we ended up on together and the same with respect to the energy side of the business.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And finally, when we think about the combined cycle fleet at Power, you've seen a significant uptick in terms of how much they can run. Just curious, from a physical standpoint, what do think the -- I guess to use the word maximum output level like how hi
componenttext: And finally, when we think about the combined cycle fleet at Power, you've seen a significant uptick in terms of how much they can run. Just curious, from a physical standpoint, what do think the -- I guess to use the word maximum output level like how high do think they can physically run from a capacity factor standpoint versus where they've been running for the last 12 to 24 months?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't think that there's a physical limit to what they can do. I mean, they're ultimately going to be taken off-line for maintenance like any other facility would. But there's nothing that stops those plants from running as long as they are called. Ther
componenttext: I don't think that there's a physical limit to what they can do. I mean, they're ultimately going to be taken off-line for maintenance like any other facility would. But there's nothing that stops those plants from running as long as they are called. There's not a refueling outage like you see out of a nuclear plant where you have to shut the unit down to refuel it but periodically there's a major maintenance that goes on in these facilities, where the unit needs to be worked on. I think we have the advantage as well with the new units that we have of having a kind of clean and new unit that won't have that effect for a period of time when it starts up.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, we've also had a couple of significant improvement programs on our combined cycles. We've improved the gas test, which has actually allowed us to stretch out the major maintenance cycles and modestly improve the heat rates. And I'll double check the
componenttext: Mike, we've also had a couple of significant improvement programs on our combined cycles. We've improved the gas test, which has actually allowed us to stretch out the major maintenance cycles and modestly improve the heat rates. And I'll double check the numbers. We'll certainly show them in March, but I think our forest outage rage have job even if our capacity out but has gone up which is always a great time, right, means we are taking better care of the machines. They're running at about 55%, 66% capacity factor right now. You never want to promise 100% on any mechanical device, but I've not picked up from any of our team that worried about about us overtaxing these units.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then last one, Ralph, just curious your thoughts on the impact, if any, of the Ohio PPA contracts and what that means for the competitive market dynamics and design in PJM.
componenttext: And then last one, Ralph, just curious your thoughts on the impact, if any, of the Ohio PPA contracts and what that means for the competitive market dynamics and design in PJM.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it depends on how that's structured, right. I mean, clearly there was a situation in New Jersey under what we call the LCAPP law where the statute mandated that winners of those contracts bid at 0 and clear the auction, and that was just an egregi
componenttext: Yes, so it depends on how that's structured, right. I mean, clearly there was a situation in New Jersey under what we call the LCAPP law where the statute mandated that winners of those contracts bid at 0 and clear the auction, and that was just an egregious attempt to cross artificially capacity prices in the region. So we are participating in an industry group in Ohio to make sure that whatever is agreed upon doesn't artificially move the market in a way that disadvantages participants who don't have the protection of these contracts. I'd like to think that Ohio has been a long-standing supporter of competitive markets, and whatever gets structured out there gets structured in that way. But while I'd like to think we're going to carefully monitor what actually is decided to maximize the chance that, that is indeed what happens.

componenttext: Yes, the $1.7 billion total is $1.2 billion to the utility and $500 million to Power, and that runs you out through '19. That comes in through '18.

componenttext: Okay, and so part of that, at the utility, you were going to be accruing into the next case. Is that generally the way you're going to deal with the bonus depreciation accounting at the utility?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way to think about it, Gregg, is to the extent of Transmission, the impact of that will come through on a contemporaneous basis. So we will, while bonus was approved after we filed our formula rate for the 2016 year, we know that there's
componenttext: Yes, I think the way to think about it, Gregg, is to the extent of Transmission, the impact of that will come through on a contemporaneous basis. So we will, while bonus was approved after we filed our formula rate for the 2016 year, we know that there's more a call from an accounting perspective. We'll do that true up in our filings. As we go forward, you see that true up every year with respect to the Transmission piece of the bonus. Similarly with elements related to Energy Strong, with elements related to GSMP, all the clause-related updates will take place as we file those contemporaneous and near-contemporaneous filings. And then the balance of what's left was what really sits on the base amount for PSE&G. That will await the next rate case.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Travis Miller of MorningStar.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Travis Miller of MorningStar.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you guys looked across your entire CapEx program both Power and PSE&G, what parts of that make you most nervous? And is there nervous that you would not meet the budget, as you set out, or nervous that you won't meet either that allowed
componenttext: I was wondering if you guys looked across your entire CapEx program both Power and PSE&G, what parts of that make you most nervous? And is there nervous that you would not meet the budget, as you set out, or nervous that you won't meet either that allowed return sure hurdle rates that you've set out for those projects?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we're nervous about anything, Travis, we make sure we take action to fix it so we don't stay nervous. But I know you know that. I guess, I'd say the biggest things that we pay attention to are regulatory and environmental mandates that don't add to the
componenttext: If we're nervous about anything, Travis, we make sure we take action to fix it so we don't stay nervous. But I know you know that. I guess, I'd say the biggest things that we pay attention to are regulatory and environmental mandates that don't add to the return expectations of our shareholders, and quite candidly, on occasion, don't really benefit customers commensurate with the cost that need to be put into it. But other than that, as you well know, we show up at a lot of places to make acquisitions and to expand our asset base [indiscernible] so I don't think anyone would ever accuse us of being bullish or undisciplined in how we spend our money. And the good news is that most of that environmental spending is behind us. So we've talked a lot about, hey, we're building 3 combined cycle units and let's make sure we have the team in place to manage those because they're not all within a city block of each other. We got one in Maryland, one in New Jersey, one in Connecticut. I spent 1.5 hours yesterday with our head of fossil talking about what his needs are, how we can make sure that those are met. So I'd say, in general it's mandates that don't produce the customer or shareholder benefit that the regulator thinks that they do. Fortunately, most of those are behind us. And to the extent that if we didn't respond to the expanded construction program in Power, I would be nervous about that. But we are responding. And I guess, the proof that I'd put forth for you on that is we have quadrupled in the past 5 years that transmission program and we deliver those projects on schedule and on budget.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's great. Ralph, one more, you mentioned the word retail in the past, and I was wondering if you could update that's still in the lexicon of strategy?
componenttext: Okay, that's great. Ralph, one more, you mentioned the word retail in the past, and I was wondering if you could update that's still in the lexicon of strategy?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But it remains in the lexicon as a defensive move to help us make sure that we can be more effective in managing our basis risk and it's going to go a long way to that, it is not a retail place. There are things we can do other than retail, but we are dis
componenttext: But it remains in the lexicon as a defensive move to help us make sure that we can be more effective in managing our basis risk and it's going to go a long way to that, it is not a retail place. There are things we can do other than retail, but we are disciplined, cautious, as you know, I'm not a big fan of the retail business. Everybody falls in love with it in a declining price environment, that is typically where you can make a lot of money in retail, it's when prices rise and people are cut short for whatever reasons that life isn't quite so pleasant. So we would look at it purely as a small part of our output purely from a defensive purposes of managing basis risk. And we're still looking at that and working on it.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Stephen, we've seen -- as I think you are aware, we've carved out for ourselves kind of a modest size portfolio, really the 250 megawatts DC are I think consists of 14 or 15 projects. So these things range in size like 5 megawatts to 50 megawatts and m
componenttext: So Stephen, we've seen -- as I think you are aware, we've carved out for ourselves kind of a modest size portfolio, really the 250 megawatts DC are I think consists of 14 or 15 projects. So these things range in size like 5 megawatts to 50 megawatts and many more closer to 5 than to 50. And we ask very rigid return expectations. They're all supported by 25 to 30-year PPAs and they meet those return expectations. Generally, those returns are not available in some of the larger projects, and we've developed a couple of partners who are really good about bringing us opportunities that they know they can execute on. So they're willing to work with us. I do see that continuing to grow. It's mostly driven by state RPSs. And I don't think we've have baked in a number in terms of what size that will be. So when we talk about our capital program, there isn't $1 of those projects in there. Yet, if I look, look back in the past 3 or 4 years, we look pretty consistently during anywhere from $100 million to $200 million of projects.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016

componenttext: That brings us to an end. I'm going to turn the call back over to Ralph.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Kathleen. So we look forward to seeing you all in 2 weeks. But really, I hope there are 3 key points you take away from what Dan and I talked about. So first of all, we are genuinely excited about Power's positioning. We've long had low-cost nucle
componenttext:
Thanks, Kathleen. So we look forward to seeing you all in 2 weeks. But really, I hope there are 3 key points you take away from what Dan and I talked about. So first of all, we are genuinely excited about Power's positioning. We've long had low-cost nuclear, and we've had a pretty good, highly efficient combined cycle fleet but in 3 years, we've been have just an outstanding highly efficient combined cycle fleet. And all of our assets are going to be well-positioned. And, I mean, well-positioned in the broadest sense of the word. There will be near load, it will be clean, there will be diverse fleet. We'll continue to look at opportunities to improve upon that fleet, but you really should recognize that we've talked for a long time now about these 3 new units, and I don't foresee any circumstances at present that would suggest any additional new build on the horizon for us. Second point is the utility growth continues. I mean we averaged 13% growth over the last 5 years and if you just take our '15 results in the midpoint of the utility guidance for '16, we're going to grow it 14%. And yet utility builds go down yet again this year because the expiration of some charges. So the utility will represent 16% of earnings at that point and it's doing stuff that's a very important to customers, and we'll just continue marching along that path. 
So we had a good year is the final point, and I think you will find that when we get together on March 11, the next 5 years look even better. So look forward to explaining that further when we see you in New York. Thanks, everyone.
