componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Lapides with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you, on the Salem issue, can you talk a little bit about other plants over the years that have seen similar issues and whether any of those turned into any more major related items or is having issues with kind of baffle bolted, very standard, very co
componenttext: Can you, on the Salem issue, can you talk a little bit about other plants over the years that have seen similar issues and whether any of those turned into any more major related items or is having issues with kind of baffle bolted, very standard, very common occurrence. I have to be very honest as a nonnuclear engineer that were baffle bolts is a little baffling to me.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, for the question. I am glad you asked it. So to my knowledge, in DC [indiscernible] issue in 2010, Indian Point had an issue starting a month or so ago, there have been a handful, I think it's like 6 or 8 European plants. These are not, t
componenttext: Thanks, Michael, for the question. I am glad you asked it. So to my knowledge, in DC [indiscernible] issue in 2010, Indian Point had an issue starting a month or so ago, there have been a handful, I think it's like 6 or 8 European plants. These are not, to my knowledge, these are not life threatening issues, they are literally 800 volts, typically that secure these metal plates, we call them baffles to the reactor vessel and they are under pressure. There's a pressure gradient because of the high temperatures being that flows through the holes in these baffles and you just get a mechanical stress, in our case that's 832 bolts. They are typical of pressurized water reactors. So that's why I mentioned earlier, to Paul's question that we would have to look at Salem 2 again it is an extra feeling outage or little pass visual inspection in '15, it would not be an issue for Hope Creek because that's a boiling one reactor. So I don't want to suggest anything other than we have to complete the inspection, but none of the prior instance has there been an issue that has the threatened the plants going forward integrity or anything of that nature.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And coming to the regulated side, the ENG, as you guys do most years since your Analyst Day, you layout a CapEx forecast that obviously shows in year 3 through 5 somewhat of a decline from years 1 through 2. Can you talk about the things, your goa
componenttext: Got it. And coming to the regulated side, the ENG, as you guys do most years since your Analyst Day, you layout a CapEx forecast that obviously shows in year 3 through 5 somewhat of a decline from years 1 through 2. Can you talk about the things, your goals in 2016, in terms of actually -- I don't want to call it backfilling, but the types of the projects that you could see showing up in the 2018 to 2020 time frame that might keep CapEx at a more similar level to '16 and '17 or even at a higher level. What are the types of projects? What do you have to do from the regulatory construct process to get those approved?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So there's a whole host of that Michael. There's ongoing renewable portfolio standard commitments that could result in some additional solar work. There are a couple of special projects that we haven't named publicly on the distribution system that
componenttext: Sure. So there's a whole host of that Michael. There's ongoing renewable portfolio standard commitments that could result in some additional solar work. There are a couple of special projects that we haven't named publicly on the distribution system that involve major customers that would benefit the entire customer base that we'll be pursuing. There's always new and additional work that comes out of it, PJM-RTEP, and that's the kind of stuff you'll see us looking at and potentially announcing in '16. However, the major backfill in the out years and the plan will be announced in '16 because they're pretty new and that will be a continuation of our guest system modernization plan, and a continuation of Energy Strong. And the reason why we won't announce those in '16 is because we're only 1.5 years into Energy Strong and we're only 6 months into GSMP, and both were both 3 year programs, give or take, a few months on some unique aspects of it. So you're right to say that we have historically backfilled the years 4 and 5. I think there's a very high probability, we'll do the same this time. But I think that in terms of the goals for '16, it will be more -- some significant distribution projects that we have and potentially some solar work that -- to keep this data on it's RPS targets, you'll see us pursuing in the near term.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta with Citigroup.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So quickly on the storage point, I know it was an interesting debate and you may have found some relevant point. So that was really thoughtful. I just want to understand, you're mentioning storage more from a Transmission perspective, but just taking back
componenttext: So quickly on the storage point, I know it was an interesting debate and you may have found some relevant point. So that was really thoughtful. I just want to understand, you're mentioning storage more from a Transmission perspective, but just taking back to storage more from a generation feed perspective. If you did have the 10 to 20-year window horizon as you talked about, how would you think of the implications for your gas fleet? And just generally, for the markets in general if you did think storage was coming whenever, 10 years, 20 years down the road, how do you see the implications for the Power generation for your fleet and just generally in the U.S?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think there are 3 uses for storage. Right, one is to the extent that one has some localized distribution reinforcement that can be more economically achieved through storage rather than substation enhancement. Second would be, your classic arbit
componenttext: I mean, I think there are 3 uses for storage. Right, one is to the extent that one has some localized distribution reinforcement that can be more economically achieved through storage rather than substation enhancement. Second would be, your classic arbitrage between peak and off-peak power, which has become less of a economic driver nowadays, just given the abundance of natural gas. Third could be, sort of a similarity to that, which is to offset the intermittency associated with renewables. But in terms of using batteries as speakers, I mean, I think that you just have to take a look again at the dollars per kW, and my goodness, the gas engine just keep getting more and more efficient and storage seems to be losing in that race to keep up with them. So I think there are multiple applications. I didn't mean to suggest that we would only tend to one. What I was trying to point out is whether the application is on the supply side or whether it's a customer reliability side, whether it's providing peaking services, other ancillary services. We don't have a religious fervor around one technology or another, we look at them all the time.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough, that's very helpful. And then secondly, from M&A perspective, there's a number of generation assets clearly in the market and potentially more coming. And you've talked about at some point of separation as well. So how do you fit all that in?
componenttext: Fair enough, that's very helpful. And then secondly, from M&A perspective, there's a number of generation assets clearly in the market and potentially more coming. And you've talked about at some point of separation as well. So how do you fit all that in? Are you looking to get to critical mark? Is there opportunity here to acquire some assets and then get to critical mass where you think you can at some point, separate. How are you thinking about that opportunity right now?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean that's pretty much what we've told the world. Right that we see 3 very tangible, tactical reasons for remaining integrated. As the financial synergies between Power's cash generation and Utility's cash needs. It's the customer build synergies
componenttext: Yes. I mean that's pretty much what we've told the world. Right that we see 3 very tangible, tactical reasons for remaining integrated. As the financial synergies between Power's cash generation and Utility's cash needs. It's the customer build synergies between the customers of Power serves and the customers that PSE&G serves, and Power's prices go down, PSE&G distribution rates go up quite candidly. And last but not the least is the benefits of scale associated with the corporate support functions. And as Power continues to pursue growth opportunities outside PGME's, the first 2 issues become a less important, right. You have more customers that are not PSE&G customers that we will be serving in New England and in New York State, you'll have more need for Power's funds from operations going to Power as opposed to going over to the Utility, and as both companies get bigger then the corporate support synergies become less on a percentage basis. And the reason why I say outside of PGME's is because we're pretty much preemptive from making any acquisitions within PGME's. And given the slow growth and demand, we're not big fans of greenfield development of PGME's. It just -- you quickly run into an oversupply situation. Having said all of that, we have demonstrated that we're pretty bad in acquiring assets. By that, I mean, we seem to have a more conservative view of where the market is going, and are consistently outbid, Keys being the one exception to that, which I believe was largely because of our confidence in our ability to manage construction risk that perhaps others did not possess and also some of the portfolio benefit it brought us in terms of PJM West. So we look all the time at generation assets. We have an anti -- I was  about to say anti- coal bias, that sounds very political, and I didn't mean it that way. But just given the direction environmental regulation you won't see us taking a look at any coal expansions in terms of new assets, but we do look in our target markets, which would be the rest of PJM, New England and New York State. We just have to get at the right price, and we're going to remain disciplined and what that means for us.

componenttext: No. It was -- so the equipment is not routinely on-site, but we are in the process right now of securing that equipment while we do the ultrasonic testing. I mean, this is, as I said this is -- there's at least 10 other reactors that had this issue in the past. And...

componenttext: No, I understand. And I was just trying to understand whether -- they were saying the delay was caused by equipment not being on-site. So...

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a robotic device that needs to go in and change out the bolts and replace those that are -- they fail the ultrasonic testing, right it's not something you can send a person into the vessel.
componenttext: I think there's a robotic device that needs to go in and change out the bolts and replace those that are -- they fail the ultrasonic testing, right it's not something you can send a person into the vessel.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: From a critical past perspective to the inspections that are ongoing now need to take place first. So we have some time off the critical test to be able to secure that kind of equipment.

And I'm curious if like a stong Q3 might get us back to the midpoint or maybe we're looking at sort of below the bottom end and a strong Q3 gets us back within. Is there anymore color you can kind of give on that?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Ben, the range is the range. And historically, what we do is after Q1, we really don't modify our numbers or push people up or down and just leave with the range. After Q2, sometimes we may move $0.05 one way or another if we think if there is a d
componenttext: Yes. So Ben, the range is the range. And historically, what we do is after Q1, we really don't modify our numbers or push people up or down and just leave with the range. After Q2, sometimes we may move $0.05 one way or another if we think if there is a definitely bias one way or another in terms of verbally guiding. And then typically, after Q3 is when we, if there's a need, tighten the range one way or the other. And so we're $2.80 to $3. It was a tough winter. And we've got a lot of focus on our operations and our cost efficiencies and the range always assumes that the rest of the year is normal weather. We never assume that the weather is going to suddenly do something different than what the weather service predicts as a normal.

componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Bren. So thanks, everyone, for being on the call. And the main message I hope you took away is my favorite message, which is steady as she goes. We have Utility capital program that's proceeding as planned, Power construction program of the 3 combined cycle units is on schedule and on budget. Our operations are strong throughout the Enterprise, and the balance sheet is as solid as ever. I know Kathleen and Dan have some travels coming up in the next couple of weeks. And then the 3 of us have some travels coming up in the next couple of months. So hopefully, we'll get to see most, if not all of you, during those travels. Thanks a lot, and we'll talk soon.

Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Brent, and I am your event operator for today. I would like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Friday, April 29, 2016, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern today until 11:30 p.m. Eastern on May 6, 2016. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released our first quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier today. The release and attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.co
componenttext:
Thank you, Brent. Good morning, everyone. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released our first quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier today. The release and attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.com, under the Investors section. We also posted a series of slides that detail operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended March 31, 2016, is expected to be filed shortly. Please read the full disclaimer statement and the comments we have on the difference between operating earnings and GAAP results. As you know, the earnings release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimate changes, unless, of course we are required to do so.
Our release also contains adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings as well as adjusted EBITDA for PSEG Power. Please refer to today's 8K or our other filings for a discussion of the factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, and expectations and for a reconciliation of operating earnings and adjusted EBITDA to GAAP results. I would now like to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President, Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. And joining Ralph on the call is Dan Cregg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions. Thank you.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. PSEG delivered solid results for the first quarter in the face of rather mild winter temperatures and low prices for natural gas and energy. Earlier this morning, we reported
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining us today. PSEG delivered solid results for the first quarter in the face of rather mild winter temperatures and low prices for natural gas and energy. Earlier this morning, we reported operating earnings for the first quarter of 2016 of $0.91 per share versus operating earnings of $1.04 per share in last year's first quarter. Extreme temperature differences between the first quarter of this year and the first quarter of last year provide the backdrop for this quarter's operating results.
The first quarter of 2016 was 10% warmer than normal and the fifth warmest on record. The month of March, in particular, was extremely mild with heating degree days 25% lower than normal. Weather for the first quarter was also 27% warmer than the first quarter of 2015, but last year was the coldest on record.
Our results were strong in the face of this headwind. PSE&G's execution on its expanded capital investment program continues to provide a growing source of earnings. PSE&G is expected to invest $3 billion in 2016 as part of its 5-year $12 billion capital program. Transmission is the largest part of PSE&G's effort, representing 60% of planned spending.
PSE&G's investment program and a continued focus on controlling costs will help drive our forecast for double-digit growth in PSE&G's 2016 operating earnings.
PSE&G's execution of our capital program is expected to yield best-in-class growth rate in rate base of 8% per year for the 5-year period ending 2020. PSE&G continues to develop a pipeline of investment opportunities that also made New Jersey's policy objectives and has customer support.
Now as for PSEG Power, it has been focused on operating in an environment of low gas prices for years. The availability and low price of gas, and the need to meet more stringent reliability requirements has added new urgency to the company's efforts to improve its cost structure and efficiency. Power's capital program also represents an important response to today's market. Power's $2 billion of investment in 3 new combined cycle gas turbines will add approximately 1,800 megawatts of clean, reliable and efficient capacity to its fleet. 
Construction of the Keys plant in Maryland and the Sewaren unit in New Jersey are on schedule to meet their 2018 operating dates. Bridgeport Harbor is expected to be available for a 2019 commercial operation date. The addition of this new capacity will transform Power's fleet. Power's baseload nuclear capacity will be complemented by a flexible, low-cost fleet of combined cycle gas units capable of responding to the market. The fleet's carbon footprint is also expected to decline with the addition of the new, clean gas-fired capacity as nuclear generation continues to represent approximately 50% of the fleet's output. As I said, we remain focused on operating efficiently and safely. PSEG Power has made judicious reductions in its nuclear workforce, and is working closely with the industry to identify additional means of reducing its cost structure, to assure the availability of this clean nuclear resource well into the future. Our goal is to capture these savings for the year to help offset the impact of low gas prices on earnings. 
Separately from operations, we were very pleased with some recent actions in defense of competitive markets. In particular, we were delighted with the U.S. Supreme Court's unanimous decision affirming the Fourth Circuit's decision in Hughes versus Maryland. Since that decision, the U.S. Supreme Court also dismissed the New Jersey case, allowing to stand the lower court ruling that the so-called LCAPP contracts are unconstitutional. A recent action at FERC is also constructive. I'm referring to the orders issued by FERC earlier this week granting the complaints filed by EPSA and others, which called into question some approvals granted by the Public Utility Commission of Ohio. A separate complaint, brought by a number of generating companies regarding the scope of the minimum offer price rule under RPM, is still pending at FERC. While owners of existing assets with out-of-market contracts will not be directly restricted in the upcoming base residual auction regarding how they can bid the affected units, the lack of certainty regarding FERC approval of such contracts should at least neutralize some, if not all of the incentives under the contracts to bid without regard to the unit's actual cost of operations.
We believe that a competitive market is the best approach for ensuring that there is a supply of electric capacity to meet customer demand at the lowest cost.
Our company-wide efforts are focused on building an infrastructure that improves system reliability, reduces emissions and supports the needs of customers. Our strategy is working and it is made possible by the contribution from our dedicated employees, who support our efforts in countless ways. Their focus on the mission of providing safe, reliable energy has allowed us to meet the needs of customers and shareholders.
We are maintaining our operating earnings guidance for the full year of $2.80 to $3 per share. Our guidance assumes normal weather for the remainder of the year. As we move forward, the weather and market conditions during the third quarter will be important for both PSEG Power and PSE&G. Current market conditions and the complete absence of a winter require that we maintain our relentless focus on identifying cost efficiencies and maintaining strong operating performance. With that, I'll turn the call over to Dan, who will discuss our financials in greater detail.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the first quarter of 2016 of $0.91 per share versus operating earnings of $1.04 per share in last year's first quarter.On Slide 4, we provided you with a r
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph, and good morning, everyone. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the first quarter of 2016 of $0.91 per share versus operating earnings of $1.04 per share in last year's first quarter.
On Slide 4, we provided you with a reconciliation of operating earnings to net income for the quarter, and we've provided you with information on Slide 8 regarding the contribution to operating earnings by business for the quarter. Additionally, Slide 9 contains a waterfall chart that takes you through the net changes quarter-over-quarter in operating earnings by major business.
And I'll now walk through each company in more detail. For PSE&G, shown on Slide 11, we reported operating earnings for the first quarter of 2016 of $0.52 per share compared with $0.47 per share for the first quarter of 2015. PSE&G's first quarter results reflect the impact of revenue growth associated with an expansion of its capital investment program, which more than offset the effect of unfavorable weather conditions on electric and gas demand.
Returns on PSE&G's expanded investment in transmission added $0.04 per share to earnings in the quarter. And the first quarter also benefited from the recovery of revenue on PSE&G's Distribution investment under its Energy Strong program. 
This increase in revenue improved quarter-over-quarter earnings comparisons by $0.01 a share. As Ralph mentioned, weather in the first quarter was warmer than normal and significantly warmer than conditions experienced last year. The negative impact of the extreme differences in weather on gas demand in revenue quarter-over-quarter was largely offset by the gas weather normalization for us. The decline in electric sales and revenue, however, as a result of the extreme differences in weather reduced quarterly earnings comparisons by $0.02 per share.
Lower taxes more than offset an increase in O&M expense due to the absence of insurance recovery of storm costs received in the year-ago quarter. These items together added $0.02 per share to quarter-over-quarter earnings.
Economic indicators continued to improve. Employment in New Jersey has increased for 28 consecutive months, as the unemployment rate has declined to 4.3%. And the housing market has also experienced an improvement. However, this improvement in economic growth was outweighed during the quarter by mild weather. The variability in quarterly data for weather normalized electric and gas sales has been high, given the extreme weather conditions, making it difficult to discern a trend in demand when analyzing just the quarterly data. But data for the trailing 12 months indicates weather normalized electric sales were flat for the period ended March of 2016.
And in terms of weather normalized gas demand, a 0.3% decline in sales in the first quarter was led by a 1.5% decline in heating demand from the residential sector, which also is influenced by the large weather adjustment quarter-over-quarter. And on a trailing 12-month basis, gas sales increased by 1.8% year-over-year.
PSE&G's capital program remains on schedule and PSE&G invested approximately $725 million in the first quarter as part of its planned $3 billion capital investment for 2016.
Also as you may recall, PSE&G implemented a $146 million increase in annual transmission revenue under the company's transmission formula rate filing, which took effect this past January. This increase in revenue, adjusted to reflect the impact of bonus depreciation and updates of spending in prior years, will be reflected in PSE&G's earnings throughout the year. However, we're maintaining our forecast of PSE&G's operating earnings for 2016 of $875 million to $925 million.
Moving to Power, as shown on Slide 18, PSEG Power reported operating earnings for the first quarter of $0.36 per share and adjusted EBITDA of $416 million, compared with $0.55 per share and adjusted EBITDA of $626 million for the first quarter of 2015. Adjusted EBITDA excludes the same items as our operating earnings measure as well as income tax expense, interest expense, depreciation and amortization, and major maintenance expense at Power's fossil generating facilities.
The earnings release and Slide 19 provide you with a detailed analysis of the impact on Power's operating earnings quarter-over-quarter.
And we have also provided you with more detail on generation for the quarter on Slide 21. PSEG Power's first quarter results were impacted by the extremely mild weather conditions experienced this year in comparison to the year-ago period.
A decline in capacity revenue, associated with the June 2015 retirement of the HEDD, or High Electric Demand Day, peaking units in PJM reduced quarter-over-quarter earnings by $0.04 per share. Lower output due to the mild weather conditions, coupled with lower average prices on energy hedges, reduced quarter-over-quarter earnings by $0.09 per share.
And a weather-related decline in total gas send-out to commercial and industrial customers and lower prices combined to reduce quarter-over-quarter earnings on gas sales by $0.12 per share.
Lower O&M expense improved quarter-over-quarter earnings by $0.05 per share, and the reduction in interest expense added $0.01 to earnings per share.
Now let's turn to Power's operations. Output from Power's fleet declined 9% in the quarter as a result of the reduced demand and lower wholesale market prices. Output from the Cold fleet reduced, during the first quarter, a decline of 1 terawatt hour from 2.5 terawatt hours in the year ago quarter, as low gas prices affected the dispatch of coal. Output from the combined cycle fleet declined 0.2 terawatt hours to 3.7 terawatt hours, with the decline in demand. The nuclear fleet, however, experienced a 0.6 terawatt hour improvement in output to 8.4 terawatt hours for the quarter.
The fleet operated at an average capacity factor of 99.7% in the quarter, and the nuclear fleet's performance benefited from an improvement in availability at Salem as well as an increase in capacity at Peach Bottom. And you may recall that the extended Power upgrade work was completed at Peach Bottom last year, and this work added 130 megawatts to our share of the station's capacity.
Power's gas-fired combined cycle fleet has access to low-cost gas, which continues to provide it with an advantage relative to market prices. However, the lack of demand and the lack of volatility in the market, given the mild weather and an excess supply of gas, pressured spark spreads, which were significantly lower compared to last year's levels. 
Overall, Power's gross margin declined to $43.80 per megawatt hour from $47.32 in the year ago quarter. Power's revising its forecast of output for 2016 to 52 to 54 terawatt hours from its prior forecast of 54 to 56 terawatt hours. The updated range for output incorporates the impact of the abnormally warm weather in the first quarter.
This range also incorporates an anticipated extension of the Salem 1 refueling outage. A visual inspection during the current refueling outage at Salem 1, which began on April 14, revealed damage to a series of bolts located inside the reactor vessel. The need to conduct further testing to repair and replace the bolts is expected to extend the refueling outage.
To provide some context, as the rule of thumb, a delay in Salem's refueling outage of 30 days would reduce generation by approximately 0.5 terawatt hour. And under this scenario, nuclear fleets' capacity factor for the year would be reduced by about 1.5% to 91% from the current forecasted capacity factor of 92.5% for the year. And the actual outage duration will be determined after ongoing inspection work is completed.
As shown on Slide 24, approximately 70% to 75% of anticipated production for the April to December period of 40 terawatt hours is hedged at an average price of $49 per megawatt hour. Our open position for the remainder of 2016 is more than adequate to cover the potential for a decline in output at Salem from our original forecast.
For 2017, Power's hedged 50% to 55% of its forecast generation of 54 to 56 terawatt hours at an average price of $49 per megawatt hour. And for 2018, approximately 20% to 25% of the forecast generation of 59 to 61 terawatt hours is hedged at an average price of $49 per megawatt hour. The forecast increase in generation in 2018 reflects the commercial operation of the Keys and Sewaren combined cycle units. 
The hedge data for 2016 continues to assume PGS hedges representing 11 to 12 terawatt hours. As we mentioned to you last quarter, there are items included in our average hedge price, which influence Power's revenue but don't support Power's gross margin. Our average hedge price for the remainder of 2016 reflects an increase in cost elements such as transmission and renewables associated with serving our full requirement hedge obligations. The increase year-over-year in these nonmargin revenue items is approximately 1 to 2 megawatt hours.
We continue to forecast operating earnings for Power in 2016 of $490 million to $540 million. And the forecast for operating earnings represents adjusted EBITDA of $1,320,000,000 to $1.4 billion for the full year, which compares to $1,563,000,000 of adjusted EBITDA in 2015.
I'll briefly address as well Enterprise and Other's operating results. And for the first quarter, we reported operating earnings of $0.03 per share compared with operating earnings of $0.02 per share last year in the first quarter. The increase in operating earnings quarter-over-quarter reflects contractual payments associated with the operation of PSEG-Long Island and certain tax items at PSEG Energy Holdings. And we continue to forecast full year operating earnings for 2016 from PSEG Enterprise and Other of $60 million.
And finally, with respect to financings and other, PSEG closed the quarter with $592 million of cash on the balance sheet with debt at the end of March representing 44% of our consolidated capital.
During the quarter, PSE&G issued $850 million of securities, consisting of $300 million of 5-year notes at 1.9% and $550 million of 30-year notes at 3.8% while redeeming $171 million of long-term debt. And we remain in a position to finance our current capital program without the need for the issuance of equity. We continue to forecast operating earnings for the full year of $2.80 to $3 per share.
That concludes my comments and I will now turn the call back over to the operator for your questions.

componenttext: I just had a quick question on the lower generation in the first quarter from the milder weather. Is that actually a net negative or a positive, because you could not run your fleet and then procure the power at a lower cost to fulfill the financial hedges?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the hedges are supplied at a lower cost even though we've locked in the price, so that's good news. But as you know, we are naturally long. So whenever demand is down, that creates a drag for Power. There's a more modest drag on the Utility. It has a w
componenttext: So the hedges are supplied at a lower cost even though we've locked in the price, so that's good news. But as you know, we are naturally long. So whenever demand is down, that creates a drag for Power. There's a more modest drag on the Utility. It has a weather normalization on the gas business, but no such thing on the electric business. So a reduced demand due to mild weather would create a slight drag there, Neel.

componenttextpreview: So we don't know yet, Paul. The outage started, I think was April 14, and that would have been a fairly standard refueling outage. We normally don't give dates on that, for obvious reasons due to market sensitivity. But we're in the middle right now of do
componenttext: So we don't know yet, Paul. The outage started, I think was April 14, and that would have been a fairly standard refueling outage. We normally don't give dates on that, for obvious reasons due to market sensitivity. But we're in the middle right now of doing some testing to see how many of the bolts are damaged. And so until we finish that, we won't know exactly how long the outage is. But I should point out, even when we know, we typically don't announce that to the marketplace.

componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, so clearly Salem 2. But we did inspect Salem 2 in 2015. Because I mean, this is an industry problem that's been around since 1998. So this is not something that is unique to us or unheard-of before. But Salem 2 passed visual inspection in '15
componenttext: Yes. I mean, so clearly Salem 2. But we did inspect Salem 2 in 2015. Because I mean, this is an industry problem that's been around since 1998. So this is not something that is unique to us or unheard-of before. But Salem 2 passed visual inspection in '15. And Salem 1 was scheduled to have the more intrusive inspection in 2019, but we're a couple of years ahead of schedule there. I'll just remind you, Salem 2 was 6 years younger than Salem 1, to the extent that this is a degradation over time, that should have an influence.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Weinstein with UBS.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Recently, we saw ConEd enter into agreement to purchase gas storage and pipeline assets in Pennsylvania and New York. And we have also seen other large utilities making acquisitions of gas assets and utilities. And given the PennEast interest that you hav
componenttext: Recently, we saw ConEd enter into agreement to purchase gas storage and pipeline assets in Pennsylvania and New York. And we have also seen other large utilities making acquisitions of gas assets and utilities. And given the PennEast interest that you have already, what is your view of the current market for gas-related acquisitions and what's your own interest in expanding further?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I would say that our interest in expanding further is low to 0. In terms of our position in PennEast, quite candidly, every gas sale lessee in New Jersey has a position in that. And we just thought that it was important to help participate in brin
componenttext: Yes. So I would say that our interest in expanding further is low to 0. In terms of our position in PennEast, quite candidly, every gas sale lessee in New Jersey has a position in that. And we just thought that it was important to help participate in bringing those consumer benefits to our gas customers. As you know, PSE&G has almost 2 million gas customers. It's a really different business, Michael. I serve on the board of a company that's involved in the pipeline business, and I just think we're really good at the knitting that we do and I'd like to stick to that. So I am not second-guessing others, please don't misinterpret. I mean they have their own unique reasons for leaning in that direction. But typically, the corporate structure is different there, mostly MLPs. They have a fairly different financial proposition. And they're not without their challenges nowadays as well. So that may be a great time to go in, to buy in. There's a wrath of sighting challenges associated with this. We're experiencing that in PennEast, there was a major pipeline, and I'm sure you're aware of, in New York State that recently had an unpleasant surprise. So it's a very challenging business with fairly different DNA than what we have in our company. And I like the DNA and the match that our company has with the operations that we're responsible for.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does the current PEs in the gas utility space, on the LDC space, does that also put you off in terms of future opportunities?
componenttext: Does the current PEs in the gas utility space, on the LDC space, does that also put you off in terms of future opportunities?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that's a different subject. But the short answer to that is, yes. I mean, I understand that debt is fairly inexpensive. Dan, hopefully, impressed you with the numbers he reported for our Utility. And you could make acquisitions accretive at very,
componenttext: Yes. So that's a different subject. But the short answer to that is, yes. I mean, I understand that debt is fairly inexpensive. Dan, hopefully, impressed you with the numbers he reported for our Utility. And you could make acquisitions accretive at very, very attractive premiums to the target, but the question we always ask ourselves is just because money is relatively inexpensive, what are the alternate uses for that. And simply paying a very, very rich premium and still having accretion may not be your best choice. And we've been very clear, our priorities are: Number 1, organic growth. And number 2, supporting the dividend. and then number 3 will be share repurchase. As I have said to many people, paying a 20-plus PE to someone seems to me to be a bad idea when I know a great company that's trading at a 14 or 15 PE that has the ticker symbol of PEG. So again, I, hopefully, am not going to cause second-guessing or critical of others' decisions, but those are the ones I'm comfortable for us.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One last question. In terms of the partnership with Vectren for competitive Transmission in MISO, do you see any other opportunities to partner with other local utilities for a similar type of partnerships?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I can't disclose any of that -- we haven't publicly disclosed. But that is an approach that we are eager to pursue. I think that there is a lot of value to be had by combining forces with someone who understands the local transmission grid and sys
componenttext: Yes. So I can't disclose any of that -- we haven't publicly disclosed. But that is an approach that we are eager to pursue. I think that there is a lot of value to be had by combining forces with someone who understands the local transmission grid and system with our expertise now having put over $2 billion to work on an annual basis for a good number of years in terms of cost and schedule management on transmission construction. I'm very proud of our team and the work that they've done. But we don't know the system everywhere in the country. So to the extent that we can combine our project management skills and our construction management know-how with people systems knowledge, that's a win-win for everyone.

componenttext: And that's right. I mean, Travis, I guess the way that -- maybe the best way to try to think about where we are from the $0.12 impact that we saw this quarter is if you were to look at each of the last couple of quarters, you would have seen last year and the year before, there was a $0.05 and a $0.04 benefit that we picked up additively over the last 2 quarters. So it's very much the absence of a winter, which has impact both on pricing and on volumes. I think the volumes were down about 1/3 and when you have that impact as well as a margin compression, we really also didn't see much volatility, which doesn't help in that market. So they all were contributions to the delta that you saw for this quarter.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Okay, great. That's helpful. What are your thoughts on Storage and how that might disrupt the Transmission plans or alternatively offer you guys investment opportunities that wouldn't be in Transmission, but could be in Storage?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: As luck would have it, I literally just came from a presentation 2 weeks ago by a director of Lawrence Berkeley Labs on storage. And his claim, don't ask me his name, because I don't remember, but he's probably easy to look up. Is that we're at least a fa
componenttext: As luck would have it, I literally just came from a presentation 2 weeks ago by a director of Lawrence Berkeley Labs on storage. And his claim, don't ask me his name, because I don't remember, but he's probably easy to look up. Is that we're at least a factor of 2 away from grid-connected storage that makes economic sense. And what he has found is that, that translated to anywhere from a 10- to 20-year time frame. Of course, when you're talking about material science, research advances, it's difficult to put up with precision. But we're agnostic, Travis, about what hardware one puts in place to serve customers. So I don't care if it's copper wire, superconducting ceramic wire, lead acid batteries, lithium batteries, flow batteries, I'm running out of technologies to start blathering and I'm starting to tread on dissertation time frames. But no, we would be more than happy to pursue things that have economic merit that provides the reliability our customers are demanding.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Gregg, as you know, we try not to outguess the forward market. We do -- however, we've said in the past, there is a tendency in the market to take a data point from 48 hours ago and a data point from 24 hours ago and extrapolate it for the next 3 year
componenttext: So, Gregg, as you know, we try not to outguess the forward market. We do -- however, we've said in the past, there is a tendency in the market to take a data point from 48 hours ago and a data point from 24 hours ago and extrapolate it for the next 3 years. And sometimes that emotional response is not as well informed by fundamentals as we'd like. But we always stay within certain guidelines. We allow our team to drift up a little bit if we think the market is being a bit bullish. And we allow them to drift down if we think the market is being overly bearish. And you'll recall, on April 14 was the former. We said we can go ahead and hedge a little bit towards the upside since the market is being somewhat bullish. And it's pretty safe to conclude that right knowledge drifting towards the bottom of our guideposts, just given the anomalously warm winter we had, and the bearishness that's crept into the market. Now having said that, that bearishness is not totally unjustified, given where gas storage levels are.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then just the other thing to think about too Gregg is that, for the BJS auction to the extent that, that's a contribution across our hedge horizon, that auction usually -- it takes place every year in February. So you see little bit of a pickup in that re
componenttext: Then just the other thing to think about too Gregg is that, for the BJS auction to the extent that, that's a contribution across our hedge horizon, that auction usually -- it takes place every year in February. So you see little bit of a pickup in that regard in the first quarter's change.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you -- on the Salem issue, can you talk a little bit about other plants over the years that have seen similar issues and whether any of those turned into any more major related items or is having issues with kind of baffle bolts, very standard, very c
componenttext: Can you -- on the Salem issue, can you talk a little bit about other plants over the years that have seen similar issues and whether any of those turned into any more major related items or is having issues with kind of baffle bolts, very standard, very common occurrence? I have to be very honest as a nonnuclear engineer that were baffle bolts is a little baffling to me.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Michael, for the question. I am glad you asked it. So to my knowledge, in DC Cook had an issue in 2010. Indian Point had an issue starting a month or so ago. There have been a handful, I think it's like 6 or 8, European plants. These are not, to m
componenttext: Thanks, Michael, for the question. I am glad you asked it. So to my knowledge, in DC Cook had an issue in 2010. Indian Point had an issue starting a month or so ago. There have been a handful, I think it's like 6 or 8, European plants. These are not, to my knowledge, these are not life threatening issues, they are literally 800 volts typically that secure these metal plates, we call them baffles, to the reactor vessel and they are under pressure. There's a pressure gradient because of the high temperatures being that flows through the holes in these baffles and you just get a mechanical stress. In our case, we have 832 bolts. They are typical of pressurized water reactors. So that's why I mentioned earlier, to Paul's question, that we would have to look at Salem 2 again at this next revealing outage, although it passed visual inspection in '15. It would not be an issue for Hope Creek, because that's a boiling-water reactor. So I don't want to suggest anything other than we have to complete the inspection, but in none of the prior instances has there been an issue that has the threatened the plants going forward integrity or anything of that nature.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And coming to the regulated side, the ENG, as you guys do most years since your Analyst Day, you lay out a CapEx forecast that obviously shows in year 3 through 5 somewhat of a decline from years 1 through 2. Can you talk about the things, your go
componenttext: Got it. And coming to the regulated side, the ENG, as you guys do most years since your Analyst Day, you lay out a CapEx forecast that obviously shows in year 3 through 5 somewhat of a decline from years 1 through 2. Can you talk about the things, your goals in 2016, in terms of actually -- I don't want to call it backfilling, but the types of projects that you could see showing up in the 2018 to 2020 time frame that might keep CapEx at a more similar level to '16 and '17 or even at a higher level? What are the types of projects? What do you have to do from the regulatory construct process to get those approved?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So there's a whole host of them, Michael. There's ongoing renewable portfolio standard commitments that could result in some additional solar work. There are a couple of special projects that we haven't named publicly on the distribution system that
componenttext: Sure. So there's a whole host of them, Michael. There's ongoing renewable portfolio standard commitments that could result in some additional solar work. There are a couple of special projects that we haven't named publicly on the distribution system that involve major customers that would benefit the entire customer base that we'll be pursuing. There's always new and additional work that comes out of it, PJM-RTEP, and that's the kind of stuff you'll see us looking at and potentially announcing in '16. However, the major backfill in the out years of the plan will be announced in '16 because they're pretty new and that will be a continuation of our Gas System Modernization Plan, and a continuation of Energy Strong. And the reason why we won't announce those in '16 is because we're only 1.5 years into Energy Strong and we're only 6 months into GSMP, and both were both 3 year programs, give or take, a few months on some unique aspects of them. So you're right to say that we have historically backfilled the years 4 and 5. I think there's a very high probability we'll do the same this time. But I think that in terms of the goals for '16, it will be more -- some significant distribution projects that we have and potentially some solar work that -- to keep this data on its RPS targets, you'll see us pursuing in the near term.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Praful Mehta with Citigroup.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So quickly on the storage point, I know it was an interesting debate and you may have found some relevant point. So that was really thoughtful. I just want to understand, you're mentioning Storage more from a Transmission perspective, but just taking it b
componenttext: So quickly on the storage point, I know it was an interesting debate and you may have found some relevant point. So that was really thoughtful. I just want to understand, you're mentioning Storage more from a Transmission perspective, but just taking it back to storage more from a generation feed perspective, if you did have the 10 to 20-year window horizon as you talked about, how would you think of the implications for your gas fleet and just generally, for the markets in general? If you did think storage was coming whenever, 10 years, 20 years down the road, how do you see the implications for the Power generation for your fleet and just generally in the U.S.?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I think there are 3 uses for storage. Right, one is to the extent that one has some localized distribution reinforcement that can be more economically achieved through storage rather than substation enhancement. Second would be, your classic arbit
componenttext: I mean, I think there are 3 uses for storage. Right, one is to the extent that one has some localized distribution reinforcement that can be more economically achieved through storage rather than substation enhancement. Second would be, your classic arbitrage between peak and off-peak power, which has become less of an economic driver nowadays, just given the abundance of natural gas. Third could be, sort of a similarity to that, which is to offset the intermittency associated with renewables. But in terms of using batteries as peakers, I mean, I think that you just have to take a look again at the dollars per kW, and my goodness, the gas engines just keep getting more and more efficient and Storage seems to be losing in that race to keep up with them. So I think there are multiple applications. I didn't mean to suggest that we would only consider one. What I was trying to point out is whether the application is on the supply side or whether it's a customer reliability side, whether it's providing peaking services, other ancillary services. We don't have a religious fervor around one technology or another. We look at all, all the time.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough, that's very helpful. And then secondly, from M&A perspective, there's a number of generation assets clearly in the market and potentially more coming. And you've talked about at some point of separation as well. So how do you fit all that in?
componenttext: Fair enough, that's very helpful. And then secondly, from M&A perspective, there's a number of generation assets clearly in the market and potentially more coming. And you've talked about at some point of separation as well. So how do you fit all that in? Are you looking to get to critical mass? Is there opportunity here to acquire some assets and then get to critical mass where you think you can at some point, separate. How are you thinking about that opportunity right now?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, that's pretty much what we've told the world, right, that we see 3 very tangible, tactical reasons for remaining integrated. It's the financial synergy between Power's cash generation and Utility's cash needs. It's the customer build synergie
componenttext: Yes. I mean, that's pretty much what we've told the world, right, that we see 3 very tangible, tactical reasons for remaining integrated. It's the financial synergy between Power's cash generation and Utility's cash needs. It's the customer build synergies between the customers that Power serves and the customers that PSE&G serves, and Power's prices go down, PSE&G distribution rates go up, quite candidly. And last but not the least is the benefits of scale associated with the corporate support functions. And as Power continues to pursue growth opportunities outside PGM East, the first 2 issues become less important, right? You have more customers that are not PSE&G customers that we will be serving in New England and in New York State. You have more need for Power's funds from operations going to Power as opposed to going over to the Utility. And as both companies get bigger then the corporate support synergies become less on a percentage basis. And the reason why I say outside of PGM East is because we're pretty much preemptive from making any acquisitions within PGM East. And given the slow growth and demand, we're not big fans of greenfield development in PGM East. It's just you quickly run into an oversupply situation. Having said all of that, we have demonstrated that we're pretty bad in acquiring assets. By that, I mean, we seem to have a more conservative view of where the market is going, and are consistently outbid, Keys being the one exception to that, which I believe was largely because of our confidence in our ability to manage construction risk that perhaps others did not possess and also some of the portfolio benefit it brought us in terms of PJM West. So we look all the time at generation assets. We have an anti -- I was about to say anti-coal bias, but that sounds very political, and I didn't mean it that way. But just given the direction environmental regulation you won't see us taking a look at any coal expansions in terms of new assets, but we do look in our target markets, which would be the rest of PJM, New England and New York State. We just have to get it at the right price, and we're going to remain disciplined and what that means for us.

componenttext: Can I just ask you one thing which Entity mentioned, why their outages lasted a little bit longer, is that they didn't have the equipment on-site and I don't know what that meant exactly. componenttext: No. It was -- so the equipment is not routinely on-site, but we are in the process right now of securing that equipment while we do the ultrasonic testing. This is a highly irradiated area. It's inside the reactor vessel. But we are in conversations with at least 2 vendors who claim to be able to help us do the work, and we're confident we'll be able to bring them on-site. I mean, this is, as I said this is -- there's at least 10 other reactors that had this issue in the past. And...

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: No, I understand. And I was just trying to understand whether -- they were saying their delay was caused by equipment not being on-site. So...

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a robotic device that needs to go in and change out the bolts and replace those that are -- that fail the ultrasonic testing, right. It's not something you can send a person into the vessel.
componenttext: I think there's a robotic device that needs to go in and change out the bolts and replace those that are -- that fail the ultrasonic testing, right. It's not something you can send a person into the vessel.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016

componenttext: From a critical past perspective to the inspections that are ongoing now need to take place first. So we have some time off the critical test to be able to secure that kind of equipment.

componenttextpreview: And just, I wonder if I'm maybe reading into your comments you made at the beginning of the call too much about kind of the importance of Q3. It seems like maybe you're sort of guiding us to the low end of the range. And I'm curious if like a strong Q3 mi
componenttext: And just, I wonder if I'm maybe reading into your comments you made at the beginning of the call too much about kind of the importance of Q3. It seems like maybe you're sort of guiding us to the low end of the range. And I'm curious if like a strong Q3 might get us back to the midpoint or maybe we're looking at sort of below the bottom end and a strong Q3 gets us back within. Is there anymore color you can kind of give on that?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So, Ben, the range is the range. And historically, what we do is, after Q1, we really don't modify our numbers or push people up or down and just leave with the range. After Q2, sometimes we may move $0.05 one way or another if we think if there is a
componenttext: Yes. So, Ben, the range is the range. And historically, what we do is, after Q1, we really don't modify our numbers or push people up or down and just leave with the range. After Q2, sometimes we may move $0.05 one way or another if we think if there is a definitely bias one way or another in terms of verbally guiding. And then typically, after Q3 is when we, if there's a need, tighten the range one way or the other. And so we're $2.80 to $3. It was a tough winter. And we've got a lot of focus on our operations and our cost efficiencies and the range always assumes that the rest of the year is normal weather. We never assume that the weather is going to just suddenly do something different than what the weather service predicts is a normal year.

componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Brent. So thanks, everyone, for being on the call. And the main message I hope you took away is my favorite message, which is steady as she goes. We have Utility capital program that's proceeding as planned, a Power construction program of the 3 combined cycle units that's on schedule and on budget. Our operations are strong throughout the Enterprise, and the balance sheet is as solid as ever. I know Kathleen and Dan have some travels coming up in the next couple of weeks. And then the 3 of us have some travels coming up in the next couple of months. So hopefully, we'll get to see most, if not all, of you during those travels. Thanks a lot, and we'll talk soon.
