componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name's Brand, and I am your event operator today. I would like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group's Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] .
As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Friday, July 29, 2016, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern today until 11:30 p.m. Eastern on August 5, 2016. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brand. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released our second quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier today. The release and attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.com, un
componenttext:
Thank you, Brand. Good morning. Thank you all for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released our second quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier today. The release and attachments are posted on our website at www.pseg.com, under the Investor section. 
We also posted a series of slides that detail operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended June 30, 2016, is expected to be filed shortly. 
I will read the full disclaimer statement and the comments we have on the difference between operating earnings and GAAP results, but as you know, the earnings release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimate that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimate changes, unless, of course, we are required to do so.
Our release also contains adjusted non-GAAP operating earnings. Please refer to today's 8-K or other filings with discussions of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts, and expectations and for a reconciliation of operating earnings to GAAP results. 
I would now like to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. Joining Ralph on the call is Dan Cregg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. PSEG's results for the second quarter were characterized by a tough environment for power markets, but also, with continued growth associated with PSE&G's expanded capital program. Earl
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. PSEG's results for the second quarter were characterized by a tough environment for power markets, but also, with continued growth associated with PSE&G's expanded capital program. 
Earlier this morning, we reported net income for the quarter of $0.37 per share. Operating earnings for the second quarter of 2016 was $0.57 per share. Operating earnings were in line with the $0.57 per share earning in 2015 second quarter.
The results for the quarter bring operating earnings for the first half of 2016 to $1.48 per share, which compares with operating earnings of $1.61 per share earned in 2015's first half.
Slides 4 and 5 contain the detail on the results for the quarter and the first half. PSE&G's execution on its expanded capital investment program continues to provide a growing source of earnings, and powers prudent management of reductions in O&M minimize the impact of the extended outage at sale on earnings. 
PSE&G is on track to invest $3 billion in 2016 as part of its 5-year $12 billion capital program. PSE&G's ability to earn its authorized return on investment continues to drive our forecast for double-digit growth in PSE&G's 2016 earnings. 
We continue to look for opportunities to grow in a manner that meets customers' demand for reliable, efficient and clean energy and provides the risk-adjusted return demanded by shareholders. 
In the past quarter, we have identified more than $500 million of additional investment opportunities in our regulated utility company, PSE&G. During the past quarter, PSE&G requested an extension for the New Jersey board of public utilities of its existing landfill ground field solar program. The program would add 100 megawatts off grid connected solar facilities over 5-year period at the cost of approximately $240 million.
The program would also create 575 direct jobs in New Jersey during the construction period and allow all customers to share on the benefits of solar. We hope to see a decision on this request during the fourth quarter of this year.
In addition, PSE&G has increased its estimate of distribution capital expenditures over 2016 through '18 by $300 million to address what is commonly referred to as new business request and to replace certain aging equipment and infrastructure.
As I mentioned, these programs together would represent an increase of more than $500 million over PSE&G's current plans to invest $12 billion over the 5-year period ended 2020.
PSE&G's robust investment program will insure that remains one of the most reliable utilities in the nation as was demonstrated during the period of intense heat and activity experienced over the past 2 weeks.
The investment program will also improve on PSE&G's growth in rate base currently forecasted at 8% per year for the 5-year period ending 2020. 
The powers capital program is also an important response to the need of today's market, which requires that we operate at greater levels of reliability and efficiency. The planned replacement of older generating capacity at the seawall in Bridgeport station and new capacity at Keys amounts to 1,800 megawatts of new, clean and efficient gas pipe capacity over the next 3 years.
This will transform fleet and enhance its competitive position. We will see an increase in capacity, we will see an increase in reliability, we will see an increase in efficiency and we will see a reduction in carbon emission.
Although power has focused on the construction of the new combined cycle new units, power has also committed to improving the efficiency of existing capacity and ensuring its long-term availability. This can be seen through completion of a small upbreak at its peaking stations, which added 14 megawatts to capacity. Power also plans to increase the efficiency in capacity of the Bethlehem Energy Center through Advanced Gas Path subgrades in the turbines over 2017 and '18. When completed, this work is expected to have 58 megawatts to BEC's capacity. 
And the recent issuance of the final renewal permit for the sale at station that meets the requirements of Section 3 16 B of the Clean Water Act helps to assure the long-term availability of this 0 carbon generating resource. 
Finally, Power has made targeted reductions in its workforce and continues to identify additional means of reducing its cost structure to assure the availability and dispatch of the fleet in the current low price environment.
The power market over the short term continues to be characterized by an oversupply of gas. The market, however, has shown signs of improvement as gas prices have responded to a decline in production. 
The improvement in the supply picture and the development of more outlets for supply has also led to an improvement in forward basis. As we've indicated in the past, we continue to expect basis to be seasonal that is positive in the winter and neutral to negative in the summer, and so more takeaway capacity goes into operation. 
In May 2016, PSEG announced the results of the RPM auction for the 2019, 2020 -- to 2010 delivery year. Power cleared approximately 8,900 megawatts of its generating capacity at an average price of a $116 per megawatt day. The average price received by Power, while lower than prior auctions, continues to represent a premium to the average price per capacity in the RTO. 
Prices in the most recent auction reflects PSEG's downwardly revised demand forecast. Changes in the emergency transfer limits due to its transmission expansion and the effects for both new generation and unclear generation from the prior year's auction. 
However, the results from the RPM auction were in line with our expectations. Nearly all the powers clear capacity in the latest auction complies with PSEG's capacity performance requirements, and the fleet is expected to be in the position to meet PGM's requirement at 100% of capacity for 2020 to 2021 delivery year must meet those CP requirements. 
On the regulatory front, FERC has approved 2 of the 5 recommended steps to approve energy price formation. Further efforts to address transparency in the scheduling of capacity could lead to improved alignment of prices with costs. 
The EU has presented challenges. Looking forward to the second half of the year, we're maintaining operating earnings guidance for 2016 of $2.80 to $3 per share, but will be difficult to reach the upper end of the guidance even with an improvement in the Power markets, expectations for long summer weather, restoration of normal operations at Salem and ongoing cost control and management of O&M. 
Our highly skilled workforce has met the markets' challenges through the rightsizing of resources and by identifying investments that meet customers' needs. Our dedication to customer service, strong balance sheet and our ability to invest in the future of the company are expected to drive long-term value creation. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dan who will discuss our financials in greater detail and then I'll be available for further questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the second quarter of 2016 of $0.57 per share, the same as operating earnings of $0.57 per share in last year's second quarter. The reco
componenttext:
Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today. 
As Ralph said, PSEG reported operating earnings for the second quarter of 2016 of $0.57 per share, the same as operating earnings of $0.57 per share in last year's second quarter. The reconciliation of operating earnings to net income for the quarter can be found on Slide 4. 
We've also provided you with a waterfall chart on Slide 10 that takes you through the net changes in the quarter-over-quarter operating earnings by major business, and a similar chart on Slide 12 provides you with the changes in operating earnings by business on a year-to-date basis. 
I'll now review each company in a little bit more detail starting with PSE&G. PSE&G reported net income for the second quarter of 2016 of $0.35 per share compared with $0.33 per share for the second quarter of 2015 for a 6% improvement in earnings. 
Our results for the quarter are shown on Slide 14.
PSE&G's operating results for the second quarter reflect the impact of a revenue growth associated with the expansion of the company's capital investment program. Returns on PSE&G's expanded investment in transmission added $0.03 per share to earnings for the quarter. Increase and depreciation on O&M expense of $0.02 per share was partially offset by a decline in taxes and other items. The high level of depreciation is related to the growth in capital spending, and higher levels of OEM reflect spending on vegetation management. 
In New Jersey, economy continues to show steady growth and unemployment levels have shown improvement from a year ago. The variability and quarterly data for weather normalized electric and gas sales has been high, given extreme weather comparisons. Weather-normalized electric sales reflect growth in residential and commercial customers, which is offset by continuing decline in the industrial sector and increased energy efficiency measures. So our trailing 12-month basis, weather-normalized electric sales were essentially flat.
PSE&G's capital program remains on schedule. PSE&G investment approximately $1.4 billion during the first half of the year as part of its planned 2016 capital program of $3 billion.
As Ralph mentioned, PSE&G has identified investment opportunities, which if approved, will increase PSE&G's 5-year capital program by approximately $500 million to $12.5 billion, and you should expect the majority of this increase in spending will occur between 2016 and 2018.
Once again, all of these growth will be funded without the need to issue new equity. As you may recall, PSE&G implemented $146 million increase in annual transmission revenue under the company's transmission formula rate filing, which took effect this past January. This increase in revenue adjusted to reflect the impact of bonus depreciation and update suspending the prior years will be reflected in PSE&G's earnings throughout the year. We'll also remind you that the quarter-to-quarter earnings comparisons associated with PSE&G's investment in transmission are not expected to be even during the second half of the year. The recognition of bonus depreciation in 2015 and some other expenses at the end of the year reduced PSE&G's fourth quarter 2015 earnings by about $0.04 per share. The contributions to earnings from the Energy's strong capital program will also be more evident during the second of the year, given growth in the Energy Strong-related spending, the shape of the rate structure which places more emphasis on demand charges during the third quarter.
We are increasing our forecast of PSE&G's operating earnings for 2016 to $900 million to $935 million from $875 million to $925 million, and a change in corporate cost control efforts and a strong start to summer weather. 
Now let's turn to Power. PSE&G Power reported a net loss for the quarter of $11 million or $0.02 per share compared with net income of $166 million or $0.33 per share for the year ago quarter. Operating earnings were $0.18 per share for the second quarter of 2016 and adjusted EBITDA was $272 million as compared with operating earnings of $0.22 per share and adjusted EBITDA of $301 million for the second quarter of 2015.
And our adjusted EBITDA excludes the same items as operating earnings as well as income tax expense, interest expense, depreciation and amortization and major maintenance at Power's generating facilities. 
The earnings release in Slide 20 provide you with detailed analysis of Power's operating earnings quarter-over-quarter. We've also provided you with more detail on generation for the quarter and the first half of the year on Slide 22 and 23.
Power's operating results for the second quarter reflect the impact of the known decline in PJM capacity revenues and average prices and energy hedges, in addition to the effective and expanded refueling outage at Salem 1. Declining capacity revenue associated with the June 2015 retirement of capacity in PJM reduced quarter-over-quarter income by $0.02 per share, and capacity revenue during the second half of 2016 should approximate the revenues received during the last 6 months of 2015.
Earnings comparisons in the quarter were also impacted by a decline in the average price received on energy hedges as well as lower market prices and gas volumes, which together, reduced Power's quarter-over-quarter income by $0.03 per share and a decline of output reduced income by $0.01 per share. 
Our reduction in O&M expense improved Power's quarter-over-quarter income by $0.07 per share. This improvement reflects the absence in 2016 of costs incurred during the second quarter of 2015 for the refueling outage at the Hope Creek nuclear plant, which is 100% owned by Power and major maintenance work at our combined cycle units. And the quarterly comparisons also benefited from targeted reduction in O&M and Power's nuclear and fossil stations as well as from changes in the management of work schedules associated with the sale on one of the refueling outage, which will minimize the overall cost of the outage. 
As we mentioned during the first quarter earnings call, the Salem 1 refueling outage, which began on April 14, would be extended to repair degraded level holes. The volt replaement has been completed and the unit is in the process of returning to service. 
During the quarter, an increase in depreciation expense was offset by a decline in interest expense. However, in absence in 2016 of tax credits received in the year-ago quarter and other tax items contributed to a reduction in quarter-over-quarter income of $0.05 per share. 
Turning to Power's operations. Output at Power's generating facilities declined 6% in the quarter as a result of lower wholesale market prices and reduced demand. Output from the gas-fired combined cycle fleet declined slightly to 4.4 terawatt hours from 4.6 terawatt hours, given mild weather conditions relative to the year-ago quarter. Low gas prices impacted the dispatch of Power's coal-fired fleet and during the quarter, the output from the coal fleet declined to 0.9 terawatt hours from 1.3 terawatt hours.
Output from the nuclear fleet was largely unchanged in the quarter with 7 terawatt hours in this quarter versus 7.1 terawatt hours in the year-ago quarter. The impact of the extended outage at Salem was largely offset by an increase in output at Peach Bottom, and completion of the extended Power operated peach bottom aired at 130 megawatts in the aggregate to Power's interest in the station. 
Salem 2 is out of service for 3 days at the end of the quarter and remains out of service. The unplanned outage at Salem 2 is the result of an electrical fault and reactor's nonnuclear balance of plant. And the extension of the outage at Salem 1 into July and the unplanned outage at Salem 2 will have a continuing effect on performance in the third quarter. 
Power's gross margin in the second quarter declined to $38.54 per megawatt hour from $40.15 per megawatt hour. Power's margin in the quarter experienced only a modest benefit from the gas-fired combined cycle fleet access to low-cost gas. 
A lack of demand and low volatility in the market, given an excess supply of gas, pressured spark spreads. 
The power markets over the last month have seen prices move to higher levels, given the impact on gas supply from hotter-than-normal weather and declines in production. And improvement in lower end prizes will help margins on base load units as an increasing regional gas prices will also support margins at the gas-fired combined cycle fleet.
For the year, Power's providing forecast of output to 50 to 52 terawatt hours from a prior forecast of 52 to 54 terawatt hours, and the updated forecast incorporates the results for the first half of the year and takes into account the extension of the outage of both units at Salem.
As shown on Slide 26, approximately 75% to 80% of anticipated production for the second half of 2016 of 25 to 26 terawatt hours is hedged at an average price of $50 per megawatt hour. For 2017, Power has hedged 55% to 60% of its forecast generation of 53 to 55 terawatt hours at an average price of $48 a megawatt hour. And for 2018, Power has hedged approximately 25% to 30% of forecast generation of 58 to 60 terawatt hours at an average price of $46 per megawatt hour. 
The forecasted increase in output for 2018  reflects the commercial start-up of a new gas-fired combined cycle capacity at the keys and C1 stations. The percentage of energy hedge for 2017 and 2018 is slightly greater than what we communicated to you earlier this year and in line with our practice. We've adjusted our forecast to Power's full year 2016 operating earnings to $460 million to $525 million from $490 million to $540 million to incorporate the results for the first half of the year. 
The revised forecast represents an adjusted EBITDA of $1.27 billion to $1.375 billion. 
I'll turn to PSEG Enterprise and other. The net income for PSEG Energy Holdings and Enterprise in the second quarter of 2016 was $19 million or $0.04 per share versus net income of $12 million and $0.02 per share for the second quarter of 2015. The increase in quarter-over-quarter income reflects contractual payments associated with operation of PSEG Long Island and certain tax items at PSEG Energy Holdings. We raised our forecast for the full year of operations to $65 million.
Our financial position remains strong. PSEG closed the quarter ended June 30, 2016, with $648 million of cash on its balance sheet, with debt at the end of the quarter representing 45% of consolidated capital. And during the quarter, Power issued $700 million of 3% 5-year senior notes due in the year 2021. 
We do not foresee the need to issue equity to finance our expanded capital program. And as Rob mentioned, we are maintaining our forecast of operating earnings for the full year of $2.80 to $3 per share. And with that, we'll be happy to take any questions.

componenttext: I'm wondering if when we look ahead generally to 2019, 2020 when you guys have new plan online and PJM in new region south and the other plans that our proposed, what are your thoughts on spark spreads? Obviously, we've seen what's happened with the capacity markets. What are your thoughts on what's happened to spark spreads?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So, Travis, I mean, perhaps we'll have 3 plants up. We'll have one in Connecticut, one in New Jersey and one in Maryland, and it really depends upon the infrastructure that's being built and of location. As you know, all of those sites do have gas on the
componenttext: So, Travis, I mean, perhaps we'll have 3 plants up. We'll have one in Connecticut, one in New Jersey and one in Maryland, and it really depends upon the infrastructure that's being built and of location. As you know, all of those sites do have gas on the property, but we're seeing an increase imports on the regional spark spreads. Right now, with our region, we're seeing sparks spreads given access to natural gas of about $20. At Petco, it's pretty close to that. It's [indiscernible] saying  could be as high as $23. So I mean, we certainly made this investment decisions on the expectation that the combination of either locked in or anticipated capacity prices plus the spark spreads would allow us to recover our cost to capital on that zone. So, as you know, our history is we don't usually picking up what the different market is telling us. But right now, the local spark spreads as defined region by region is in the $20 range.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So therein lies the value of diversified fleet. One would expect that as infrastructures get built from the regions to mostly southeastern markets, that you'll see an increase -- a decrease in price in other parts of the country, which don't have that acc
componenttext: So therein lies the value of diversified fleet. One would expect that as infrastructures get built from the regions to mostly southeastern markets, that you'll see an increase -- a decrease in price in other parts of the country, which don't have that access. And an increase in price here, which will diminish our regional spark spread advantage, but that should also then help our nuclear plant. So it's been an ongoing source of pride for us that diversity of technology and fuel allows us to deliver some consistently in terms of the margins that we're able to capture. And then, of course, one cannot ignore the seasonal variation that will persist even once the infrastructure is built.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Julian. Thank you for asking the question because I want to make sure that there's clarity of understanding around that. There's a lot going on in the nation around clear, right? I don't know the latest numbers. I think 10 to 15 plants are rumored to
componenttext: Yes, Julian. Thank you for asking the question because I want to make sure that there's clarity of understanding around that. There's a lot going on in the nation around clear, right? I don't know the latest numbers. I think 10 to 15 plants are rumored to be at risk of retiring, half a dozen have retired. Our dilemma is that as active industry participants frustrated by an absence of carbon value given to nuclear plant and seeing what's happening around us, as we're trying to engage policymakers in the conversation, that nuclear is not getting the credit that it deserves. Our challenge is quite was economically. So notwithstanding the importance of carbon, I think the motivation in other markets are some of the near-term economic consequences of shutting those plants given the lack of profitability. So we don't have that situation. We're glad we don't have that situation, but it does sort of impair our ability to have the same level of interest and participation in the discussion. So we've been talking about fuel diversity. We've been talking about 90-plus percent capacity factors and what it would mean should long-term forces require the replacement of that, whatever those long-term forces might be. But it is kind of a difficult conversation to have, given how many pressing problems are staring policymakers in the face right this minute. So on the 1 hand, I don't want to go on. We feel strongly that nuclear is not getting the credit, i.e. the price that it deserves, but we cannot and we do not make the claim that our plans are at any kind of economic risk in the near term the way others are.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016

componenttext: No, no, no. We are having early conversations in both forms about what that kind of more accurate representation of the value could look like and we're informing people who don't study the stuff as much as we do about what's being proposed in New York State and what's been discussed in Connecticut and what didn't happen in Vermong, in Massachusetts and Wisconsin and one that led to and what doesn't to be happening in Illinois. So we're not just walking around saying boy, I wish the world is different. We're talking to people who care about these things, about what the consequences have been in places were nothing took place and what would happen, what's been proposed in other places. At PJM,  I think there's much more of a focus on reliability associated with such large quantities of baseball power that don't have the seasonal challenges of access to gas and backup fuels. But I think that historically, PJM, of course, is not due to should as an implementer of environmental policy. So the conversation can be broader at the state level than the state call to process at PJM.

componenttext: Got it. In a completely separate question just in terms of power, are you guys think all about extending the footprint there? Obviously, you guys have been in different diversification efforts. Where do you think you are with respect to having adequate scale in that business and the desirability for the investment? I was -- yes, I'll leave it there.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, no. I think -- so Power has stated its desire to expand and moving in New York and PJM. We think that those are the most efficient markets, given the combination of energy and capacity value in all Cleveland. We have also said that we do not anti
componenttext: Yes. No, no. I think -- so Power has stated its desire to expand and moving in New York and PJM. We think that those are the most efficient markets, given the combination of energy and capacity value in all Cleveland. We have also said that we do not anticipate any new build. We felt we had 3 very unique situations. But in the flat demand, we're all pretty much in oversupply condition arguably all 3  locations and facilities through and 2 them. Injecting new supply doesn't appear to be a winning proposition. From the point of view of Power's scale, in terms of its reach, I'd like to see if it have a little bit more of a robust portfolio outside of PJM than it currently has, but it certainly would be one of the largest, if not the largest, independent power producer on its own, if that's where you headed with your question. Power doesn't have a lot of megawatts, but it's financial strength and its profitability, I think, are quite unique. And we're very proud of and we work hard to preserve that in making our operating and investment decisions. So there's -- so the way we would intend in the near term to grow power is the way we've been trying to, which is through selective acquisitions of existing supply. As you know, we've not been successful at doing that. We -- the 1 project we landed were the Keys project and they are probably because our perception of construction risk management was different than others. So I hope that answers your question.

componenttextpreview: Fair enough. All right. And secondly, in terms of prices, I know you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you want to buy further capacity prints. I wanted to get a sense for how you're looking at long-term capacity prices in PJM. And also, what was dr
componenttext: Fair enough. All right. And secondly, in terms of prices, I know you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you want to buy further capacity prints. I wanted to get a sense for how you're looking at long-term capacity prices in PJM. And also, what was driving or what is like the minimum threshold that you looked at when you were making your investment decisions? Is there a particular price capacity prices need to stay at to get your IRR?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in terms of longer term, as you know, we don't forecast prices. What we think will be different about next year's auction than this year is a couple of factors. Number one is the requirement that 100% of the assets be CP compliant. Number two, we will
componenttext: So in terms of longer term, as you know, we don't forecast prices. What we think will be different about next year's auction than this year is a couple of factors. Number one is the requirement that 100% of the assets be CP compliant. Number two, we will have a market effective to recent announcement, an April announcement by car netizen that a wheel that they were party to they will no longer make use of. And at that, we don't have the effect of net transfer into our region of about 400 megawatts, which will now no longer be the case. Also, we don't anticipate the kind of step change in PJM's demand forecast that took place prior to the last auction. We have been the primary builder of major transmission and while we still have a very, very robust transmission program, most of those projects are not involved in significant transfer capabilities. They are more at the 69 to 230 KV [ph] level within the zone. The second half of your question, what did we look at? So we do have an internal rate return expectation. That is obviously well above our utility return expectations. And we look at the combination of energy margin and capacity margin when making the decision. Suffice to say, obviously, the fact that we're going ahead and building the prices that we realized last year in the auction and this year in Connecticut were sufficient for us to go ahead. So there's no one magic number in terms of capacity that says go ahead and build. It's a combination of capacity and energy together over the long term that we look at.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've seen a number of your peers announce later investment in utility scale renewables. And while I appreciate your earlier comment that you're not looking to expand at Power, I was wondering if you could comment on renewable outlook interior piece, give
componenttext: We've seen a number of your peers announce later investment in utility scale renewables. And while I appreciate your earlier comment that you're not looking to expand at Power, I was wondering if you could comment on renewable outlook interior piece, given just how quickly renewable cost have been declining and how improvements in technology have changed the landscape over the last couple of years.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, we don't have any peers. That's #1. That's a personal point of view. Number  two, in terms of renewables, we've been active on 2 fronts. On regulated side, we have about 300 megawatts that are in 12 or 14 states. I've lost
componenttext: Sure, Brian. Well, first of all, we don't have any peers. That's #1. That's a personal point of view. Number  two, in terms of renewables, we've been active on 2 fronts. On regulated side, we have about 300 megawatts that are in 12 or 14 states. I've lost track. And we specifically embarked on a crawl, walk,run strategy. Actually right now, we're jogging. And those projects have done well. Everyone in those have met their performance. In fact, most of them slightly exceeds the performance. Most of our solar investment, however, has been cut to trade in PSE&G, and that's been a blend of rooftop funded solar where we don't own the assets but we have regulatory assets that support the rooftop and then grid connected. As you know, in New Jersey, grid connected is measured in single-digit megawatts as opposed to a double or triple digit megawatts  Notwithstanding impressive price improvements on these installations, they still are substantially above conventional technology power prices. So our estimates right now are that in New Jersey, people pay anywhere from $4 to $6 a month for solar energy, and that's typical residential homeowner. Obviously, the average homeowner means that a bunch of people pay, more bunch of people pay less. And all our customers survey information suggest that, that is at or above the level that people are comfortable paying. So our pursuit of solar in PSE&G is really driven by the RPS and the desire to achieve those policy-mandated targets at as low a price as possible. And doing things 3 and 4 megawatts at a time on landfill is a lot less expensive than doing them 2 or 3 kilowatt hour at a time on rooftops. But one has to be careful even 3 and 5 megawatts at the time as still in practice. So long-standing fans of solar. We're not apologist for it, but we do have to balance the billing tax. And so we pursue those opportunities in State, in accordance with the RPS and in other states, in accordance with those utilities need to meet their RPS and secure those investments through Power purchase agreements.

So when you look at Power, you look at its balance sheet and you look at selected acquisitions to increase scale, what you're seeing around you, does it sort of open up the doors and maybe looking at nuclear?

Every indication of the availability of natural gas and the duration of that availability and the likely price range that we would see would suggest that new nuclear in emerging company would not be an economic wise thing to do.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think what I'm relating to is pre-existing nuclear assets that could potentially have contracted cash flow for the next 2 years.
componenttext: No. I think what I'm relating to is pre-existing nuclear assets that could potentially have contracted cash flow for the next 2 years.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you have contracted cash flows and have met the hurdle rate, and we certainly think that nuclear has a long-term future. But as we were saying just a few minutes ago with the bulk, others seem to invariably when we show up to buying existi
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you have contracted cash flows and have met the hurdle rate, and we certainly think that nuclear has a long-term future. But as we were saying just a few minutes ago with the bulk, others seem to invariably when we show up to buying existing asset, they had a couple of dollars to forward price curve and we don't tend to win. So in terms of purchasing decisions assets so much is driven by kind of the winner's curse and your view of where forward prices are going and now I think a more disciplined approach we're saying that we're not smarter than the market. So I would think the practicality of that would be somewhat limiting.

componenttext: Yes. So I'll let Dan answer about the tension, but when we look at O&M on a -- always time to check out on O&M perspective. We look at it every day. So we just extended contracts with 6 out of our 8 units [ph] Not all of them on utility. But after our 3 largest utility units were included in that 6 out of 8, and those were all reasonable escalation. They are wage increases of 3% per year, but a benefit trade-offs that reduced the overall O&M growth. So we've kept utility O&M growth to a little bit over CPI. I think it's been 2-ish percent thereabout. I don't remember exactly CPIs, but I know what our O&M growth rate it's just a little bit over 2%. And we just pay attention to that every day. We're not believers in getting inefficient before rate case and then taking cost out of the business right after. First of all, it's not great way to build confidence with regulators and it's not a good way to manage the operation. In terms of retention, yes, lower interest rates are not going to be great from the PPO, but strong market performance, which we've seen will be. componenttext: No. I mean, I that's exactly right and it's a little bit of wait and see. headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'm told by Kathleen that many of you folks have a very busy mornings with some other calls, so I'm always grateful for your participation and special thanks to today, given how much was going on [indiscernible] was. So in keeping with prior practices,
componenttext:
So I'm told by Kathleen that many of you folks have a very busy mornings with some other calls, so I'm always grateful for your participation and special thanks to today, given how much was going on [indiscernible] was. So in keeping with prior practices, let me just summarize what I hope for the key takeaways for you. 
The utility growth, driven by customer needs and policymaker priorities, is really continuing unabated. Rather than showing up the year after each estimating and telling you about what we found, we're trying to do a better job of keeping you appraised of things as we look at them. So you have a little bit over $500 million on this stuff that we've been doing, $300 million of which we're definitely going to do and a couple hundred million, which we're waiting for you to keep even on. 
Power remains quite focused on markets managing its cost, its performance and its investment decisions. With a real disciplined, what the markets telling us. So some challenging pricing environment, some great O&M control. And then third and final take away is that this balance sheet remained strong. There's no change in our dividend policy. We continue to have the belief for the opportunity, for sustained growth if that dividend that continues. And that these expanding investment needs at the utility and opportunities at the utility can be met without the equity. So I think we're on a little hiatus for a couple of weeks, and we'll be back on the road in September and certainly see all of you early in November at. So thanks very much for joining us. Have a very great rest of summer, folks.
