componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Ginger, and I am your event operator today. I'd like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Monday, October 31, 2016, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time today until 11:30 p.m. Eastern Time on November 7, 2016. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ginger.Good morning. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released third quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are posted on our website at w
componenttext:
Thank you, Ginger.
Good morning. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released third quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are posted on our website at www.pseg.com under the Investors section.
We also posted a series of slides that detail operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2016, is expected to be filed later today.
As you know, the earnings release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update those forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimate changes, unless required to do so.
Our release also contains non-GAAP operating earnings. Please refer to today's 8-K where our other investor filings for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations and for a reconciliations of non-GAAP operating earnings to GAAP results.
I would now like to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. And joining Ralph on the call is Dan Cregg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions. Thanks, Ralph.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today.PSEG reported strong results for the third quarter. Earlier this morning, we reported net income for the quarter of $0.64 per share versus $0.87 per share last year. Non-GAAP operating e
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today.
PSEG reported strong results for the third quarter. Earlier this morning, we reported net income for the quarter of $0.64 per share versus $0.87 per share last year. Non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.88 per share compared with non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2015 of $0.80 per share.
For the 9 months, we reported net income of $1.94 per share versus $2.70 per share, but non-GAAP operating earnings for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, are $2.36 per share, which compares with non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.41 per share earned during the 9 months ended September 30, 2015.
Slides 4 and 5 contain the details on the results for the quarter and the 9 months. We remain committed to our core operating philosophy of operational excellence, investing in a disciplined manner and maintaining a strong financial position to support the growth expected by our shareholders. PSE&G continues to earn its return on an expanded capital investment program. PSEG Power continues to manage through very difficult energy markets, and we continue to take strong actions to optimize both businesses in this environment.
PSEG Power has decided to retire the Hudson and Mercer coal-fired generation stations in 2017. This is sooner than we would've forecasted just a few short years ago but became inevitable in the face of changes in the energy market, which were amply demonstrated this summer. While we experienced very warm weather conditions, the abundance of low-cost gas supply, which is a benefit for our customers, kept energy prices low and is expected to keep power prices lower for longer. Careful analysis indicate it would be uneconomic to invest the capital necessary to assure the units would comply with PJM's new capacity performance reliability standards. Although the units have been dispatched infrequently, we expect the retirement of Hudson and Mercer to result in a further reduction in the fleets' emissions profile. These retirements continue the evolution of PSEG Power's fleet into a portfolio of reliable, low-cost, flexible assets capable of competing in today's market. To be clear, retirement will also aid Power's future cash flow and return profile.
The addition of 1,800 megawatts of new gas-fired capacity at Keys, Sewaren and Bridgeport Harbor over 2018 through '19 will further the transformation of the fleet.
From a supply/demand standpoint, I want to remind you that the capacity at Sewaren and Bridgeport Harbor will replace older steam and coal-fired capacity that we will retire. The new capacity will improve the fleets' efficiency and lower its cost structure. The new units remain on-time and on budget. These new units remain profitable even with the recent declines in market pricing and continue to meet our hurdles for returns, which, of course, are in excess of our return expectations that we placed on new utility investments.
By the end of this decade, our nuclear and gas-fired generation facilities will provide more than 90% of our electric output. Our nuclear fleet represents our cleanest energy resource for the foreseeable future, and our gas-fired combined cycle fleet represents an efficient flexible resource. We remain committed to operating the fleet in a safe, reliable manner and assuring their availability over the long term.
Power continues to focus on running the business efficiently and has made target reductions in its workforce and continues to identify measures to improve availability and margins in today's market. New investment opportunities for Power do not involve the construction of additional new capacity, but we continue to look for opportunities to diversify the fleet.
PSE&G also continues to identify new opportunities for growth. PSE&G is on track to invest $3 billion in 2016 as part of its 5-year $12 billion capital program. In addition, PSE&G has recently reached a settlement with key parties that provides for an extension of its existing innovative landfill and brownfield solar programs subject to BPU preapproval. The settlement allows PSE&G to expand its investment in Solar by approximately $80 million to construct 33 megawatts of grid-connected solar facilities over 3 years. We believe PSE&G's involvement in grid-connected solar -- excuse me -- extends the benefit of Solar to all of its customers at a lower cost. We anticipate the decision from the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities by year-end.
PSE&G is also requesting approval from the BPU to partner with New Jersey Transit in the development of a new $270 million substation that both would utilize and would enhance the reliability and resilience of facilities damaged by Superstorm Sandy. The new substations would enter service by the end of 2020. For me, it's hard to believe, but it's been 4 years since Superstorm Sandy struck. It touched all of our customers, and today, we've invested more than $900 million under electric and gas programs approved by the BPU to improve our systems' resilience through raising substations, building redundancy, replacing gas pipe and even trimming trees. The collaboration with New Jersey Transit on construction of a new substation represents a continuation of this type of work.
The agreement to increase our investment in Solar, our announced $300 million increase in base capital spend and PSE&G's anticipated collaboration with New Jersey Transit represent a greater than $600 million increase in PSE&G's capital program.
PSE&G's ability to earn its authorized return on investment continues to drive our forecast for double-digit growth in PSE&G's 2016 earnings.
Based on our forecast for the year, PSE&G is expected to represent more than 60% of 2016's consolidated non-GAAP operating earnings. Its investment program continues to drive annual growth in rate base of 8% for the end of decade with the potential for up to 10% with additional programs that we have planned.
We have met significant challenges to our forecast presented by the lack of winter weather and low energy pricing. Even so, consistent with our comments on the second quarter earnings call this mid--- in mid-summer, we're making a slight adjustment to the upper end of our full year guidance. We are now guiding towards 2016 non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.80 to $2.95 per share, which represents a small reduction from our prior forecast of non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.80 to $3 per share. We are confident that the investments we're making along with a focus on operational excellence and a strong balance sheet will drive long term success.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dan who will discuss our financials in greater detail.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everybody, for joining us on the call this morning.As Ralph mentioned, PSEG reported net income for the third quarter of 2016 of $0.64 per share versus net income of $0.87 per share in last year's third quarter. N
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everybody, for joining us on the call this morning.
As Ralph mentioned, PSEG reported net income for the third quarter of 2016 of $0.64 per share versus net income of $0.87 per share in last year's third quarter. Non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.88 per share versus non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.80 per share in last year's third quarter, and a reconciliation of non-GAAP operating earnings to net income for the quarter and year-to-date can be found on Slides 4 and 5.
We've also provided you with a waterfall chart on Slide 9 that takes you through the net changes in quarter-over-quarter non-GAAP operating earnings by major business, and a similar chart on Slide 10 provides you with the changes to non-GAAP operating earnings by each business on a year-to-date basis. And I'll now review each company in more detail starting with PSE&G.
PSE&G reported net income of $0.50 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared with $0.44 per share for the third quarter of 2015 for a 14% improvement. Results for the quarter are shown on Slide 12.
The improvement in PSE&G's net income for the third quarter reflects growth from its expanded investment in electric and gas transmission and distribution facilities. Returns on PSE&G's expanded investment in Transmission added $0.03 per share to net income in the quarter, and incremental revenue associated with PSE&G's Energy Strong infrastructure program added $0.02 per share to net income in the quarter.
Third quarter net income comparisons also benefited by an increase in electric demand associated with weather conditions, which were approximately 30% warmer-than-normal and 9% warmer than conditions experienced in the third quarter of 2015. The increase in demand associated with the warmer-than-normal weather added $0.01 per share to third quarter net income.
An increase in depreciation and O&M and other expense was offset by a decline in taxes and other items.
Retail electric sales increased 3.6% in the quarter, reflecting the much warmer summer weather that occurred in 2016. And on a weather-normalized basis, total sales were slightly positive versus the third quarter of 2015, with higher sales to residential and industrial customers offset by a decline in sales to commercial customers.
As Ralph mentioned, PSE&G's capital program, led by an investment and transmission, is on schedule. PSE&G is expected to invest $1.8 billion in transmission during 2016 as part of the 5-year $7.1 billion investment program to upgrade and expand the Transmission network. PSE&G's investment in transmission is expected to grow to represent approximately 45% of year-end 2016's rate base.
PSE&G recently filed an update of its formula rate for Transmission at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. And the update which reflects an increase on the level of PSE&G's investment in Transmission would provide for a $121 million increase in annual transmission revenues effective January 1, 2017, subject to FERC approval. We are maintaining our forecast for PSE&G's non-GAAP operating earnings for 2016 of $900 million to $935 million.
Now let's turn to Power. PSEG Power reported net income of $139 million or $0.27 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared with net income of $206 million or $0.40 per share for the year ago quarter. Our non-GAAP operating earnings were $0.34 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared to non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2015 of $0.33 per share. And non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for the third quarter of 2016 was $397 million versus non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2015 of $401 million.
Non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA includes the same -- excludes the same items as our non-GAAP operating earnings measure as well as income tax expense, interest expense, depreciation and amortization and major maintenance at Power's Fossil Generating Facilities.
And the earnings release on Page 18 provides you with detailed analysis of the impact on Powers' non-GAAP operating earnings quarter-over-quarter. We've also provided you with more detail on generation for the quarter and for 9 months of the year on Slide 19 and Slide 20.
Power's net income in the third quarter includes one-time pretax charges amounting to $114 million pretax, $67 million after tax with $0.13 per share related to the early retirement of the Hudson and Mercer generating stations. These one-time charges, which are excluded from Power's non-GAAP operating earnings, mainly relate to the write-down of excess coal inventories and materials and supplies as well as some other smaller items.
Power's non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter reflect a decline in the average price on energy hedges, which is partially offset by lower cost to serve load which combined to reduce quarter-over-quarter operating earnings by $0.02 per share. A decline in output during the quarter reduced the operating earnings by $0.01 per share, and a reduction in O&M expense improved the results by $0.03 per share.
An increase in depreciation expense associated with Power's capital program was more than offset by a decline in interest expense and other items, which combined to improve quarter-over-quarter net income by $0.01 per share.
As I mentioned, Power's third quarter results benefited from a reduction in O&M expense, which added $0.03 per share to net income quarter-over-quarter. Year-to-date, a reduction in Power's O&M expense has improved net income comparisons by $0.15 per share.
Management's proactive response to low energy pricing has been a major contributor to the decline in O&M, and the timing of outages and major maintenance-related work has also influenced comparisons. 
For example, in 2016, for refueling outage at Hope occurred in the spring and this year, Hope Creek's refueling outage is currently underway in the fourth quarter. O&M expense in 2015 was also elevated due to major maintenance-related work at some of the fossil stations. Although we expect O&M expense in 2016 to decline year-over-year, you should anticipate an increase in O&M for the fourth quarter, given the cost associated with the refueling of our 100% owned Hope Creek nuclear station. 
Over the long term, you can expect constant diligence in controlling the growth of O&M. 
Now let's turn to Power's operations. Output at Power is generating facilities declined 4% in the quarter and the nuclear fleet operated at an average capacity factor of 80% in the third quarter versus an average capacity factor of 95% in the year-ago quarter as output declined 12% to 6.9 terawatt hours from 7.8 terawatt hours. The decline in output reflects the impact of extended outages at the few Salem units. And as we mentioned in our second quarter earnings call, output in the third quarter would be impacted by the expansion of the refueling outages at Salem 1 through July to complete repair work on the units baffle bolts and repair work at Salem 2 and 3 pair at electrical fall. Both units have since returned to service and are operating at full capacity. 
Output from Power's gas-fired combined cycle fleet declined slightly to 5.2 terawatt hours from 5.4 terawatt hours last year. The warmer-than-normal weather conditions further increased in demand for Power's coal-fired generating stations and peeking fleet, which, together, experienced an increase in output during the quarter to 2 terawatt hours from 1.6 terawatt hours. 
Power markets in the third quarter benefited from hotter-than-normal weather, which had a favorable influence on the market, and Power was less hedged going into the quarter than a year ago, allowing the fleet to capture some upside in pricing. That said, the decline in Power's gross margin in the quarter to $41.74 per megawatt hour from $42.07 per megawatts reflects the impact of lower average prices on energy hedges. 
As we've indicated, we continue to expect basis to be seasonal. That is positive in the winter, assuming normal weather, and neutral to negative at other times of the year until more gas pipeline takeaway capacity goes into operation. 
Our continues to forecast output for 2016 of 50 to 52 terawatt hours. The forecast takes into account the extended outage at Salem as well as refueling outage at Hope Creek, which is currently under way. 
Power has reduced its forecast of generation output for '17 and '18 by approximately 3% to 4%. The revised forecast recognizes the impact of low gas prices and the potential dispatch of the Keystone and coal-fired generating stations with also some impact coming from the retirement of Hudson in Mercer's coal-fired generating stations in mid-2017.
Approximately 75% to 80% of anticipated production in the fourth quarter of 2016 of and 11 to 12 terawatt hours is hedged at an average price of $48 per megawatt hour. The average price for energy hedges for the full year approximates $50 per megawatt hour. And for 2017, Power hedged at 65% to 70% of its revised forecast of 51 to 53 terawatts of output at an average price of $47 per megawatt hour. And for 2018, Power has hedged approximately 25% to 30% of its revised forecast of 56 to 58 terawatt hours of output at an average price of $45 per megawatt hour. The hedge then did continues to assume BGS hedges will cover 11 to 12 terawatt hours of output.
The forecast of Power's non-GAAP operating earnings for 2016 has been revised to $460 million to $500 million, and the forecast represents non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for the full year of $1,270,000,000 to $1,335,000,000. 
I'd also like to point out that the retirement of Hudson and Mercer will continue to have an impact on Power's net income in the fourth quarter. In addition, the one-time charges recognized in the third quarter, Power expects to recognize incremental depreciation and amortization during the remainder of 2016 of $568 million pretax; and in 2017, Power expect to recognize incremental depreciation and amortization of $946 million pretax due to the shortening of the expected economic useful lives of Hudson and Mercer. Until the units are retired, we will continue to record normal O&M and depreciation in our non-GAAP operating earnings on an annual basis these expenses amount to an estimated $60 million and $50 million pretax, respectively. 
We should also see a reduction in Power's planned capital spending beyond 2017 of approximately $200 million to reflect the elimination of previously planned capital improvements at Hudson and Mercer. 
Now let's turn to PSEG Enterprise and other where we reported a net loss of $0.13 per share for the third quarter 2016 compared to net income of $0.03 per share for the third quarter of 2015.
Our non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.04 per share compared to non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.03 per share for the third quarter of '15. During the third quarter of 2016, Energy Holdings completed its review of estimated residual values embedded in the energy arena leverage leases. As a result of current and expected future market conditions and impairment of $86 million after tax related to the residual value of these leases was recorded in net income. The increase in non-GAAP operating in earnings quarter-over-quarter results reflect certain tax items at PSE&G Energy Holdings and contractual payments associated with the operation of PSE&G island. The forecast of PSE&G Enterprise and other full year 2016 non-GAAP operating earnings remains $65 million. 
PSEG also closed the quarter ended September 30, 2016, with $450 million of cash on its balance sheet with debt at the end of the quarter representing approximately 45% of consolidated capital. PSEG Power had debt at the end of the quarter representing 28% of capital. 
As Ralph mentioned, we've adjusted our forecast for non-GAAP operating earnings for the full year to $2.80 to $2.95 per share from $2.80 to $3 per share. 
And with that, we're ready for questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Neel Mitra from Tudor Pickering.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just based of, of some of your peers' commentary, could you comment if you're seeing any cost inflation at your nuclear plants or any upwards pressure on pricing, which you're having to contain?
componenttext: Just based of, of some of your peers' commentary, could you comment if you're seeing any cost inflation at your nuclear plants or any upwards pressure on pricing, which you're having to contain?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neel, so we have been commenting and participating in industry efforts to reverse the trend of some of the escalations in both O&M and capital. being driven by the considerations emanating from the NRC. So we're part of an effort called delivering the nuc
componenttext: Neel, so we have been commenting and participating in industry efforts to reverse the trend of some of the escalations in both O&M and capital. being driven by the considerations emanating from the NRC. So we're part of an effort called delivering the nuclear promise to take the average industry cost structure of $35 a megawatt hour down to $30 a megawatt hour. We haven't released our specific cost structure, but suffice to say that we operate slightly below the industry average. So yes, there are cost pressures, but there's an active industry effort that we are front and center and participating to both control that escalation and reverse it.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just moving to the key center. Some of your recent commentary is based off of the fact that you'd like the location in Southwest Mac with PJM. Could you comment on why that's a good location compared to some other locations in PJM for a n
componenttext: Got it. And then just moving to the key center. Some of your recent commentary is based off of the fact that you'd like the location in Southwest Mac with PJM. Could you comment on why that's a good location compared to some other locations in PJM for a new book?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a couple of reasons. First of all, it's closer to the -- it is part of the PJM hub where we do all of our hedging, so it does lend some balance to the portfolio, which is primarily PJM East where most of our assets are located. It is alert pock
componenttext: Sure. It's a couple of reasons. First of all, it's closer to the -- it is part of the PJM hub where we do all of our hedging, so it does lend some balance to the portfolio, which is primarily PJM East where most of our assets are located. It is alert pocket that is experiencing some modest degree of growth. There have been years where it looked like it was going to be about 4%, and it's been consistently the strongest pricing region from an energy market point of view in PJM in the past few years.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Your next question is from Travis Miller for Morningstar.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking at the high level, I know you guys have like to have a strong balance sheet. Were you are right now with the growth projects you have over the next 2 to 3 years, especially on the Power side, how do you see that leverage changing? And to the exten
componenttext: Looking at the high level, I know you guys have like to have a strong balance sheet. Were you are right now with the growth projects you have over the next 2 to 3 years, especially on the Power side, how do you see that leverage changing? And to the extent that it stays in this kind of range, what's the opportunity to add leverage perhaps at the apparent co or some other place on the balance sheet?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think I'll let Dan fill in remain an average about 40% for the 3 years, given current market expectations. Our floor Powers and FFO, together 30%. And as has been the case in the past, Travis, our top priority is reinvesting in the business that pred
componenttext: So I think I'll let Dan fill in remain an average about 40% for the 3 years, given current market expectations. Our floor Powers and FFO, together 30%. And as has been the case in the past, Travis, our top priority is reinvesting in the business that predominantly means reinvesting in regulated utility assets, so we continue to look for opportunities to acquire assets in Power that fill out our portfolios and compare to markets that we're interested in, that being Europe, New England and PJM. But #1, use of the balance sheet is reinvesting the business. Number two is given the cyclicality of the merchant generation business to provide support for the dividend and some of those ups and downs, so that we can provide a consistent growth rate in that dividend. And last would be to repurchase shares if we were not seeing those growth opportunities, primarily in the utility or had earnings that just dwarfed the growth in the dividend. But, Dan, I don't know if you want to add some color to some of those specifics?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. What I would say, Travis, is we have had a lot of success in finding opportunities to deploy capital and we even referenced today in excess of $600 million at the utility. So Ralph references reinvesting the capital on the businesses as opportunity #
componenttext: Yes. What I would say, Travis, is we have had a lot of success in finding opportunities to deploy capital and we even referenced today in excess of $600 million at the utility. So Ralph references reinvesting the capital on the businesses as opportunity #1, and that's what we have been able to do. And having a strong cash flow coming from the Power side of the business and the ability to provide financing there at the parent is enabling of that growth that we have throughout the business.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on those generation projects, would you expect to have a higher percentage share of debt or leverage there, such as your entire balance sheet, certainly in a small we given the relative size, would move toward more leverage? Is the question
componenttext: Okay. And then on those generation projects, would you expect to have a higher percentage share of debt or leverage there, such as your entire balance sheet, certainly in a small we given the relative size, would move toward more leverage? Is the question there simply is there going to be extra leverage at those projects as you go through the construction Phase?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016

componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you take a look at what we're investing into the business at -- on the Power side of the business and you take a look at what our cash flow is coming from the business, it pretty will supports the ability to build that a, without any equity of the parent, but without growing that leverage capacity at that leverage utilization that power.

componenttext: And to Dan's point, Travis, both Power and utility can support that capital program without an equity issuance in any of the forecast that you were able to come up.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question is from Angie Storozynski with Macquarie.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first on the Power side. Can you comment on what you're seeing on the Power base. It's not the gas base, but the power base for your combined cycle gas front? It seems that the output from your New York and New Jersey [indiscernible] have come down sli
componenttext: So first on the Power side. Can you comment on what you're seeing on the Power base. It's not the gas base, but the power base for your combined cycle gas front? It seems that the output from your New York and New Jersey [indiscernible] have come down slightly year-over-year despite this hot summer. Then we've been hearing from other power producers, gas power producers, in PJM that there's been some expansion in the negative power basis due to some congestion on transmission line as all of the gas [indiscernible] is aligning now often 24/7. Is this is phenomenon you are shifting at your units?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Angie, that is correct. So we're -- as you know, the basis differentials are very seasonal in nature and they tend to be somewhat strongly negative in the shoulders in the [indiscernible] spring in the fall. Less negative in the summer and they turn
componenttext: Yes, Angie, that is correct. So we're -- as you know, the basis differentials are very seasonal in nature and they tend to be somewhat strongly negative in the shoulders in the [indiscernible] spring in the fall. Less negative in the summer and they turn positive in the winter.  It's driven by 2 factors. You've identified both of them. One is a gas basis differentials and transmission congestion. I forgot the name of the transmission asset down in the PG&E area that is undergoing some renewal. It's [indiscernible], which, I believe according to PJM is scheduled for completion sometime next spring. That's where public information. You should check the PJM Oasis Board for confirmation that in case I have the date wrong. And, obviously, from a gas point of view, there's a much healthier degree of infrastructure that's bringing gas in the Marcellus to the New York/New Jersey region than there is going to the PJM West, which is a bit of a misnomer. It's actually south of here. And until the infrastructure corrects that arbitrage opportunity, you'll continue to see gas-based generation being less expensive to operate up here than it is down there. But we remain confident that over time, the market does correct any anomalies that exist and arbitrage opportunities that exist and there's no shortage of projects that are up either in permitting or in construction to move gas to the south. And as I said, there is a specific transmission project under way to correct the congestion that we're seeing in the BG&E area.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And now on the utility side. In your prepared remarks, you mentioned the double-digit growth rate and then you mentioned something about 8%. Can you just remind me or repeat your comments about the -- was it about the rate base growth? Or was it ab
componenttext: Great. And now on the utility side. In your prepared remarks, you mentioned the double-digit growth rate and then you mentioned something about 8%. Can you just remind me or repeat your comments about the -- was it about the rate base growth? Or was it about that longevity of the kind of double digit earnings growth?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you know, we don't forecast earnings growth and what we've been forecasting is that for the next 5 years, the utility capital program for approved programs, which support an 8% rate base growth and for programs that are fairly straightforward e
componenttext: Yes. So as you know, we don't forecast earnings growth and what we've been forecasting is that for the next 5 years, the utility capital program for approved programs, which support an 8% rate base growth and for programs that are fairly straightforward extensions of existing programs, that 8% becomes 10%. But they've not been approved by the BPU yet. Of course, as you know, rate base growth is a good indicator of earnings growth, but then one has to add load growth and subtract O&M growth and those are 2 points that are on top for the [indiscernible] . We do a good job of controlling O&M, but I would not want to promise that we will be able to control O&M at a level of 0, which is about where the load has been growing. It's like 0.1%, 0.2%. So it's suffice to say that the earnings growth will probably be a net subtraction from that rate base growth, but we don't give an example of what that number is.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Praful Mehta with Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question is from Praful Mehta with Citigroup.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question was on the separation, the generation separation side, the Power side. I know we've talked about this before, but given how ICPs are trading today, there really seems a struggle. Was wondering in that market context, does it make sense t
componenttext: So first question was on the separation, the generation separation side, the Power side. I know we've talked about this before, but given how ICPs are trading today, there really seems a struggle. Was wondering in that market context, does it make sense to think about [indiscernible] Power being separated? Or do you now reconsidering anything more keeping that [indiscernible] Power as part of the whole PSEG family?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, . We don't really have a lot of new to say about this subject. If we may -- if and when or if we were to make such a decision, it would not be a market timing decision. It would have to do with the strength of the strategic arguments in favor of work
componenttext: Yes, . We don't really have a lot of new to say about this subject. If we may -- if and when or if we were to make such a decision, it would not be a market timing decision. It would have to do with the strength of the strategic arguments in favor of working the tactical benefits that we continue to believe dominate the picture today in terms of staying together. So sure. You wouldn't try and do something in the middle of economic instability or major microeconomic disruptions, but we're not market timers. The real question is do we still have the financial synergies between the businesses? Do we still have to build synergies between the businesses? Do we still are long term investors to see the attractiveness of both in those kind of strategic flexibility, the questions that we've talked about before.

componenttext: Fair enough. And then going ahead with the nuclear discussions that you were having earlier, there is obviously discussion in New York to support nuclear  through this program. Do you see other states looking to implement something like this? Or do you see that as a possibility from New Jersey or Pennsylvania in terms of support for nuclear or carbon-free generation?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do. I think that a lot of states are realizing that these are long-lived assets. These were in nuclear plants that provide enormous benefits, both from a carbon point of view, from a fuel diversity point of view, from a liability point of view. And most
componenttext: I do. I think that a lot of states are realizing that these are long-lived assets. These were in nuclear plants that provide enormous benefits, both from a carbon point of view, from a fuel diversity point of view, from a liability point of view. And most of our markets are fairly short term in nature. Even 3-year capacity prices don't capture the full benefit of what I expect to be a fairly expensive debate on how carbon is to be priced in the future. So every state may not come up with its own remedy and regrettably, the right remedy would be a national remedy, but we don't seem to have a lot of traction in that regard right now. So I do see most of the action focused at the state-by-state level.

The utility continues to identify new customer-driven investment opportunities that fuel its growth. Lastly, there's no question, we have a relentless focus on cost control. componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. My name is Ginger, and I am your event operator today. I'd like to welcome everyone to today's conference, Public Service Enterprise Group's Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call and Webcast. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded today, Monday, October 31, 2016, and will be available for telephone replay beginning at 2:00 p.m. Eastern Time today until 11:30 p.m. Eastern Time on November 7, 2016. It will also be available as an audio webcast on PSEG's corporate website at www.pseg.com.
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kathleen Lally. Please go ahead.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Ginger.Good morning. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released third quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are posted on our website at w
componenttext:
Thank you, Ginger.
Good morning. Thank you for participating in PSEG's call this morning. As you are aware, we released third quarter 2016 earnings statements earlier this morning. The release and attachments, as mentioned, are posted on our website at www.pseg.com under the Investors section.
We also posted a series of slides that detail operating results by company for the quarter. Our 10-Q for the period ended September 30, 2016, is expected to be filed later today.
As you know, the earnings release and other matters that we will discuss in today's call contain forward-looking statements and estimates that are subject to various risks and uncertainties. And although we may elect to update those forward-looking statements from time to time, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimate changes, unless required to do so.
Our release also contains non-GAAP operating earnings. Please refer to today's 8-K where our other investor filings for a discussion of factors that may cause results to differ from management's projections, forecasts and expectations and for a reconciliations of non-GAAP operating earnings to GAAP results.
I would now like to turn the call over to Ralph Izzo, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Public Service Enterprise Group. And joining Ralph on the call is Dan Cregg, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
At the conclusion of their remarks, there will be time for your questions. Thanks, Ralph.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today.PSEG reported strong results for the third quarter. Earlier this morning, we reported net income for the quarter of $0.64 per share versus $0.87 per share last year. Non-GAAP operating e
componenttext:
Thank you, Kathleen, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today.
PSEG reported strong results for the third quarter. Earlier this morning, we reported net income for the quarter of $0.64 per share versus $0.87 per share last year. Non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.88 per share compared with non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2015 of $0.80 per share.
For the 9 months, we reported net income of $1.94 per share versus $2.70 per share, but non-GAAP operating earnings for the 9 months ended September 30, 2016, are $2.36 per share, which compares with non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.41 per share earned during the 9 months ended September 30, 2015.
Slides 4 and 5 contain the details on the results for the quarter and the 9 months. We remain committed to our core operating philosophy of operational excellence, investing in a disciplined manner and maintaining a strong financial position to support the growth expected by our shareholders. PSE&G continues to earn its return on an expanded capital investment program. PSEG Power continues to manage through very difficult energy markets, and we continue to take strong actions to optimize both businesses in this environment.
PSEG Power has decided to retire the Hudson and Mercer coal-fired generation stations in 2017. This is sooner than we would've forecasted just a few short years ago but became inevitable in the face of changes in the energy market, which were amply demonstrated this summer. While we experienced very warm weather conditions, the abundance of low-cost gas supply, which is a benefit for our customers, kept energy prices low and is expected to keep power prices lower for longer. Careful analysis indicate it would be uneconomic to invest the capital necessary to assure the units would comply with PJM's new capacity performance reliability standards. Although the units have been dispatched infrequently, we expect the retirement of Hudson and Mercer to result in a further reduction in the fleets' emissions profile. These retirements continue the evolution of PSEG Power's fleet into a portfolio of reliable, low-cost, flexible assets capable of competing in today's market. To be clear, retirement will also aid Power's future cash flow and return profile.
The addition of 1,800 megawatts of new gas-fired capacity at Keys, Sewaren and Bridgeport Harbor over 2018 through '19 will further the transformation of the fleet.
From a supply/demand standpoint, I want to remind you that the capacity at Sewaren and Bridgeport Harbor will replace older steam and coal-fired capacity that we will retire. The new capacity will improve the fleets' efficiency and lower its cost structure. The new units remain on-time and on budget. These new units remain profitable even with the recent declines in market pricing and continue to meet our hurdles for returns, which, of course, are in excess of our return expectations that we placed on new utility investments.
By the end of this decade, our nuclear and gas-fired generation facilities will provide more than 90% of our electric output. Our nuclear fleet represents our cleanest energy resource for the foreseeable future, and our gas-fired combined cycle fleet represents an efficient flexible resource. We remain committed to operating the fleet in a safe, reliable manner and assuring their availability over the long term.
Power continues to focus on running the business efficiently and has made target reductions in its workforce and continues to identify measures to improve availability and margins in today's market. New investment opportunities for Power do not involve the construction of additional new capacity, but we continue to look for opportunities to diversify the fleet.
PSE&G also continues to identify new opportunities for growth. PSE&G is on track to invest $3 billion in 2016 as part of its 5-year $12 billion capital program. In addition, PSE&G has recently reached a settlement with key parties that provides for an extension of its existing innovative landfill and brownfield solar programs subject to BPU preapproval. The settlement allows PSE&G to expand its investment in Solar by approximately $80 million to construct 33 megawatts of grid-connected solar facilities over 3 years. We believe PSE&G's involvement in grid-connected solar -- excuse me -- extends the benefit of Solar to all of its customers at a lower cost. We anticipate the decision from the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities by year-end.
PSE&G is also requesting approval from the BPU to partner with New Jersey Transit in the development of a new $270 million substation that both would utilize and would enhance the reliability and resilience of facilities damaged by Superstorm Sandy. The new substations would enter service by the end of 2020. For me, it's hard to believe, but it's been 4 years since Superstorm Sandy struck. It touched all of our customers, and today, we've invested more than $900 million under electric and gas programs approved by the BPU to improve our systems' resilience through raising substations, building redundancy, replacing gas pipe and even trimming trees. The collaboration with New Jersey Transit on construction of a new substation represents a continuation of this type of work.
The agreement to increase our investment in Solar, our announced $300 million increase in base capital spend and PSE&G's anticipated collaboration with New Jersey Transit represent a greater than $600 million increase in PSE&G's capital program.
PSE&G's ability to earn its authorized return on investment continues to drive our forecast for double-digit growth in PSE&G's 2016 earnings.
Based on our forecast for the year, PSE&G is expected to represent more than 60% of 2016's consolidated non-GAAP operating earnings. Its investment program continues to drive annual growth in rate base of 8% for the end of decade with the potential for up to 10% with additional programs that we have planned.
We have met significant challenges to our forecast presented by the lack of winter weather and low energy pricing. Even so, consistent with our comments on the second quarter earnings call this mid--- in mid-summer, we're making a slight adjustment to the upper end of our full year guidance. We are now guiding towards 2016 non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.80 to $2.95 per share, which represents a small reduction from our prior forecast of non-GAAP operating earnings of $2.80 to $3 per share. We are confident that the investments we're making along with a focus on operational excellence and a strong balance sheet will drive long term success.
With that, I'll turn the call over to Dan who will discuss our financials in greater detail.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everybody, for joining us on the call this morning.As Ralph mentioned, PSEG reported net income for the third quarter of 2016 of $0.64 per share versus net income of $0.87 per share in last year's third quarter. N
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Ralph, and thank you, everybody, for joining us on the call this morning.
As Ralph mentioned, PSEG reported net income for the third quarter of 2016 of $0.64 per share versus net income of $0.87 per share in last year's third quarter. Non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.88 per share versus non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.80 per share in last year's third quarter, and a reconciliation of non-GAAP operating earnings to net income for the quarter and year-to-date can be found on Slides 4 and 5.
We've also provided you with a waterfall chart on Slide 9 that takes you through the net changes in quarter-over-quarter non-GAAP operating earnings by major business, and a similar chart on Slide 10 provides you with the changes to non-GAAP operating earnings by each business on a year-to-date basis. And I'll now review each company in more detail starting with PSE&G.
PSE&G reported net income of $0.50 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared with $0.44 per share for the third quarter of 2015 for a 14% improvement. Results for the quarter are shown on Slide 12.
The improvement in PSE&G's net income for the third quarter reflects growth from its expanded investment in electric and gas transmission and distribution facilities. Returns on PSE&G's expanded investment in Transmission added $0.03 per share to net income in the quarter, and incremental revenue associated with PSE&G's Energy Strong infrastructure program added $0.02 per share to net income in the quarter.
Third quarter net income comparisons also benefited by an increase in electric demand associated with weather conditions, which were approximately 30% warmer-than-normal and 9% warmer than conditions experienced in the third quarter of 2015. The increase in demand associated with the warmer-than-normal weather added $0.01 per share to third quarter net income.
An increase in depreciation and O&M and other expense was offset by a decline in taxes and other items.
Retail electric sales increased 3.6% in the quarter, reflecting the much warmer summer weather that occurred in 2016. And on a weather-normalized basis, total sales were slightly positive versus the third quarter of 2015, with higher sales to residential and industrial customers offset by a decline in sales to commercial customers.
As Ralph mentioned, PSE&G's capital program, led by an investment and transmission, is on schedule. PSE&G is expected to invest $1.8 billion in transmission during 2016 as part of the 5-year $7.1 billion investment program to upgrade and expand the Transmission network. PSE&G's investment in transmission is expected to grow to represent approximately 45% of year-end 2016's rate base.
PSE&G recently filed an update of its formula rate for Transmission at the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. And the update which reflects an increase on the level of PSE&G's investment in Transmission would provide for a $121 million increase in annual transmission revenues effective January 1, 2017, subject to FERC approval. We are maintaining our forecast for PSE&G's non-GAAP operating earnings for 2016 of $900 million to $935 million.
Now let's turn to Power. PSEG Power reported net income of $139 million or $0.27 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared with net income of $206 million or $0.40 per share for the year ago quarter. Our non-GAAP operating earnings were $0.34 per share for the third quarter of 2016 compared to non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2015 of $0.33 per share. And non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for the third quarter of 2016 was $397 million versus non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for 2015 of $401 million.
Non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA includes the same -- excludes the same items as our non-GAAP operating earnings measure as well as income tax expense, interest expense, depreciation and amortization and major maintenance at Power's Fossil Generating Facilities.
And the earnings release on Page 18 provides you with detailed analysis of the impact on Powers' non-GAAP operating earnings quarter-over-quarter. We've also provided you with more detail on generation for the quarter and for 9 months of the year on Slide 19 and Slide 20.
Power's net income in the third quarter includes one-time pretax charges amounting to $114 million pretax, $67 million after tax with $0.13 per share related to the early retirement of the Hudson and Mercer generating stations. These one-time charges, which are excluded from Power's non-GAAP operating earnings, mainly relate to the write-down of excess coal inventories and materials and supplies as well as some other smaller items.
Power's non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter reflect a decline in the average price on energy hedges, which is partially offset by lower cost to serve load which combined to reduce quarter-over-quarter operating earnings by $0.02 per share. A decline in output during the quarter reduced the operating earnings by $0.01 per share, and a reduction in O&M expense improved the results by $0.03 per share.
An increase in depreciation expense associated with Power's capital program was more than offset by a decline in interest expense and other items, which combined to improve quarter-over-quarter net income by $0.01 per share.
As I mentioned, Power's third quarter results benefited from a reduction in O&M expense, which added $0.03 per share to net income quarter-over-quarter. Year-to-date, a reduction in Power's O&M expense has improved net income comparisons by $0.15 per share.
Management's proactive response to low energy pricing has been a major contributor to the decline in O&M, and the timing of outages and major maintenance-related work has also influenced comparisons.
For example, in 2015, the refueling outage at Hope Creek occurred in the spring, and this year, Hope Creek's refueling outage is currently underway in the fourth quarter. O&M expense in 2015 was also elevated due to major maintenance-related work at some of the fossil stations. So although we expect O&M expense in 2016 to decline year-over-year, you should anticipate an increase in O&M for the fourth quarter, given the cost associated with the refueling of our 100%-owned Hope Creek Nuclear Station. Over the long term, you can expect constant diligence in controlling the growth of O&M.
Now let's turn to Power's operations. Output at Power's generating facilities declined 4% in the quarter, and the nuclear fleet operated at an average capacity factor of 80% in the third quarter versus an average capacity factor of 95% in the year-ago quarter as output declined 12% to 6.9 terawatt hours from 7.8 terawatt hours. The decline in output reflects the impact of extended outages at the few Salem units. And as we mentioned in our second quarter earnings call, output in the third quarter would be impacted by the extension of the refueling outage at Salem 1 through July to complete repair work on the unit's baffle bolts and repair work at Salem 2 to repair an electrical fault. Both units have since returned to service and are operating at full capacity.
Output from Power's gas-fired combined cycle fleet declined slightly to 5.2 terawatt hours from 5.4 terawatt hours last year. The warmer-than-normal weather conditions spurred an increase in demand for Power's coal-fired generating stations and peaking fleet, which together, experienced an increase in output during the quarter to 2 terawatt hours from 1.6 terawatt hours.
Power markets in the third quarter benefited from hotter-than-normal weather, which had a favorable influence on the market, and Power was less hedged going into the quarter than a year ago, allowing the fleet to capture some upside in pricing. That said, a decline in Power's gross margin into the quarter to $41.74 per megawatt hour from $42.07 per megawatts reflects the impact of lower average prices on energy hedges.
As we have indicated, we continue to expect bases to be seasonal that is positive in the winter, assuming normal weather, and neutral to negative at other times of the year until more gas pipeline takeaway capacity goes into operation.
Power continues to forecast the output for 2016 of 50 to 52 terawatt hours. The forecast takes into account the extended outage at Salem as well as refueling outage at Hope Creek, which is currently under way.
Power has reduced its forecast of generation output for '17 and '18 by approximately 3% to 4%. The revised forecast recognizes the impact of low gas prices on the potential dispatch of the Keystone and Conemaugh coal-fired generating stations with also some impact coming from the retirement of Hudson and Mercer's coal-fired generating stations in mid-2017.
Approximately 75% to 80% of anticipated production in the fourth quarter of 2016 of 11 to 12 terawatt hours is hedged at an average price of $48 per megawatt hour. The average price for energy hedges for the full year approximates $50 per megawatt hour. And for 2017, Power has hedged at 65% to 70% of its revised forecast of 51 to 53 terawatt hours of output at an average price of $47 per megawatt hour. And for 2018, Power has hedged approximately 25% to 30% of its revised forecast of 56 to 58 terawatt hours of output at an average price of $45 per megawatt hour. The hedge data continues to assume BGS hedges will cover 11 to 12 terawatt hours of output.
The forecast of Power's non-GAAP operating earnings for 2016 has been revised to $460 million to $500 million, and the forecast represents non-GAAP adjusted EBITDA for the full year of $1,270,000,000 to $1,335,000,000.
I'd also like to point out that the retirement of Hudson and Mercer will continue to have an impact on Power's net income in the fourth quarter. In addition to the one-time charges recognized in the third quarter, Power expects to recognize incremental depreciation and amortization during the remainder of 2016 of $568 million pretax. And in 2017, Power expects to recognize incremental depreciation and amortization of $946 million pretax due to the shortening of the expected economic useful lives of Hudson and Mercer. Until the units are retired, we will continue to record normal O&M and depreciation in our non-GAAP operating earnings on an annual basis. These expenses amount to an estimated $60 million and $50 million pretax, respectively.
We should also see a reduction in Power's planned capital spending beyond 2017 of approximately $200 million to reflect the elimination of previously planned capital improvements at Hudson and Mercer.
Now I'll turn to PSEG Enterprise and other where we reported a net loss of $0.13 per share for the third quarter 2016 compared to net income of $0.03 per share for the third quarter of 2015.
Our non-GAAP operating earnings for the third quarter of 2016 were $0.04 per share compared to non-GAAP operating earnings of $0.03 per share for the third quarter of '15. During the third quarter of 2016, Energy Holdings completed its review of estimated residual values embedded in the NRG REMA leveraged leases. And as a result of current and expected future market conditions, an impairment of $86 million after tax related to the residual value of these leases was recorded in net income. The increase in non-GAAP operating earnings quarter-over-quarter results reflect certain tax items at PSEG Energy Holdings and contractual payments associated with the operation of PSEG-Long Island. The forecast of PSEG Enterprise and other full year 2016 non-GAAP operating earnings remains $65 million.
PSEG also closed the quarter ended September 30, 2016, with $450 million of cash on its balance sheet, with debt at the end of the quarter representing approximately 45% of consolidated capital. PSEG Power had debt at the end of the quarter, representing 28% of capital.
As Ralph mentioned, we've adjusted our forecast for non-GAAP operating earnings for the full year to $2.80 to $2.95 per share from $2.80 to $3 per share.
And with that, we are ready for your questions.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Neel Mitra from Tudor Pickering.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question is from Neel Mitra from Tudor Pickering.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just based off of some of your peers' commentary, could you comment if you're seeing any cost inflation at your nuclear plants or any upwards pressure on pricing, which you're having to contain?
componenttext: Just based off of some of your peers' commentary, could you comment if you're seeing any cost inflation at your nuclear plants or any upwards pressure on pricing, which you're having to contain?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neel. So we have been commenting and participating in industry efforts to reverse the trend of some of the escalations in both O&M and capital being driven by the considerations emanating from the NRC. So we're part of an effort called Delivering the
componenttext: Yes, Neel. So we have been commenting and participating in industry efforts to reverse the trend of some of the escalations in both O&M and capital being driven by the considerations emanating from the NRC. So we're part of an effort called Delivering the Nuclear Promise to take the average industry cost structure of $35 a megawatt hour down to $30 a megawatt hour. We haven't released our specific cost structure, but suffice to say that we operate slightly below the industry average. So yes, there are cost pressures, but there's an active industry effort that we are front and center and participating to both control that escalation and reverse it.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just moving to the Keys Center. Some of your recent commentary is based off of the fact that you like the location in Southwest Mac [ph] within PJM. Could you comment on why that's a good location compared to some other locations in PJM f
componenttext: Got it. And then just moving to the Keys Center. Some of your recent commentary is based off of the fact that you like the location in Southwest Mac [ph] within PJM. Could you comment on why that's a good location compared to some other locations in PJM for a new build?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. It's a couple of reasons. First of all, it's closer to the -- it is part of the PJM west hub where we do all of our hedging, so it does lend some balance to the portfolio, which is primarily PJM East for where most of our assets are located. It is a
componenttext: Sure. It's a couple of reasons. First of all, it's closer to the -- it is part of the PJM west hub where we do all of our hedging, so it does lend some balance to the portfolio, which is primarily PJM East for where most of our assets are located. It is a load pocket that is experiencing some modest degree of growth. There have been years where it looked like it was going to be about 4%, and it's been consistently the strongest pricing region from an energy market point of view in PJM the past few years.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Travis Miller for Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question is from Travis Miller for Morningstar.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking -- at a high level, I know you guys have like to have a strong balance sheet. Were you are right now with the growth projects that you have over the next 2 to 3 years, especially on the Power side, how do you see that leverage changing? And to the
componenttext: Looking -- at a high level, I know you guys have like to have a strong balance sheet. Were you are right now with the growth projects that you have over the next 2 to 3 years, especially on the Power side, how do you see that leverage changing? And to the extent that it stays in this kind of range, what's the opportunity to add leverage perhaps at the parent co or some other place on the balance sheet?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think our numbers, I'll let Dan fill in, remain, on average, above 40% for the next 3 years, given current market expectations. Our floor Powers an FFO to debt of 30%. And yes, as it's been an indication in the past, Travis, our top priority is reinv
componenttext: So I think our numbers, I'll let Dan fill in, remain, on average, above 40% for the next 3 years, given current market expectations. Our floor Powers an FFO to debt of 30%. And yes, as it's been an indication in the past, Travis, our top priority is reinvesting in the business. That predominantly means reinvesting in regulated utility assets. Although we continue to look for opportunities to acquire assets in Power that fill out our portfolios in competitive markets that we're interested in, that being New York, New England and PJM. But number 1, use of the balance sheet is reinvesting in the business. Number two is given the cyclicality of the merchant-generation business to provide support for the dividend in some of those ups and downs, so that we can provide a consistent growth rate in that dividend. And the last would be to repurchase shares if we were not seeing those growth opportunities, primarily in the utility or had earnings that just dwarfed the growth in the dividend. But, Dan, I don't know if you want to add some color to some of those specifics?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Mainly, what I would say, Travis, is we have had a lot of success in finding opportunities to deploy capital, and we even referenced today in excess of $600 million at the utility. So Ralph references reinvesting the capital on the businesses as oppo
componenttext: Yes. Mainly, what I would say, Travis, is we have had a lot of success in finding opportunities to deploy capital, and we even referenced today in excess of $600 million at the utility. So Ralph references reinvesting the capital on the businesses as opportunity #1, and that's what we have been able to do. And having a strong cash flow coming from the Power side of the business and the ability to provide financing there at the parent is enabling of that growth that we have without -- throughout the business.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on those generation projects, would you expect to have a higher percentage share of debt or leverage there such that your entire balance sheet, certainly in a small way, given the relative size, would move toward more leverage? Is -- the qu
componenttext: Okay. And then on those generation projects, would you expect to have a higher percentage share of debt or leverage there such that your entire balance sheet, certainly in a small way, given the relative size, would move toward more leverage? Is -- the question there simply is, is there going to be extra leverage at those projects as you go through the construction phase?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think, if you take a look at what we're investing into the business at -- on the Power side of the business and you take a look at what our cash flow is coming from the business, it pretty well supports the ability to build that a, without
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think, if you take a look at what we're investing into the business at -- on the Power side of the business and you take a look at what our cash flow is coming from the business, it pretty well supports the ability to build that a, without any equity at the parent but without growing that leverage capacity at that leverage utilization of that power.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to Dan's point, Travis, both Power and Utility can support the capital program without any equity issuance in any of the forecast that we're able to come up with.
componenttext: And to Dan's point, Travis, both Power and Utility can support the capital program without any equity issuance in any of the forecast that we're able to come up with.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Angie Storozynski from Macquarie.
componenttext: Your next question is from Angie Storozynski from Macquarie.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first on the Power side. Can you comment on what you're seeing on the Power base, it's not the Gas bases but the Power bases, for your combined-cycle gas plant? It seems like the output from your New York and New Jersey units have come down slightly ov
componenttext: So first on the Power side. Can you comment on what you're seeing on the Power base, it's not the Gas bases but the Power bases, for your combined-cycle gas plant? It seems like the output from your New York and New Jersey units have come down slightly over year despite this hot summer. And we've been hearing from other power producers, gas-fired producers, in PJM that there's been some expansion in the negative Power bases due to some congestion on transmission line as all of the gas pods [ph] are running now, often 24/7. Is this a phenomenon you are shifting at your units?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Angie, that is correct. So we're -- as you know, the bases differentials are very seasonal in nature. They tend to be somewhat strongly negative in the shoulders -- in the off-season this spring and the fall, less negative in the summer, and they tur
componenttext: Yes, Angie, that is correct. So we're -- as you know, the bases differentials are very seasonal in nature. They tend to be somewhat strongly negative in the shoulders -- in the off-season this spring and the fall, less negative in the summer, and they turn positive in the winter. It's driven by 2 factors. You've identified both of them. One is gas bases differentials and transmission congestion. I forget the name of the transmission asset down in the PG&E area that is undergoing some renewal. It's Bagley...

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bagley-Graceton. Up in... yes.
componenttext: Bagley-Graceton. Up in... yes.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bagley-Graceton, which, I believe according to PJM, is scheduled for completion some time next spring. That's all public information. You should check the PJM OASIS board for confirmation of that in case I have the date wrong. And then obviously, from a g
componenttext: Bagley-Graceton, which, I believe according to PJM, is scheduled for completion some time next spring. That's all public information. You should check the PJM OASIS board for confirmation of that in case I have the date wrong. And then obviously, from a gas point of view, there's a much healthier degree of infrastructure that's bringing gas in the Marcellus to the New York/New Jersey region than there is going to the PJM west region, which is a bit of a misnomer. It's actually south of here. And until the infrastructure corrects that arbitrage opportunity, you'll continue to see gas-based generation being less expensive to operate up here than it is down there. But we remain confident that over time, the market does correct any anomalies that exist and arbitrage opportunities that exist, and there's no shortage of projects that are up either in permitting or in construction to move gas to the south. And as I said, there is a specific transmission project under way to correct the congestion that we're seeing in the BG&E area.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And now on the utility side. In your prepared remarks, you mentioned the double-digit growth rate and then you mentioned something about 8%. Can you repeat -- just remind me or repeat the -- your comments about the -- was it about the rate base gro
componenttext: Great. And now on the utility side. In your prepared remarks, you mentioned the double-digit growth rate and then you mentioned something about 8%. Can you repeat -- just remind me or repeat the -- your comments about the -- was it about the rate base growth? Or was it about the longevity of the Con double digit earnings growth?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as you know, we don't forecast earnings growth, and what we've been forecasting is after the next 5 years, the utility capital program for approved programs would support an 8% rate base growth and for programs that are fairly straightforward exte
componenttext: Yes. So as you know, we don't forecast earnings growth, and what we've been forecasting is after the next 5 years, the utility capital program for approved programs would support an 8% rate base growth and for programs that are fairly straightforward extensions of existing programs, that 8% becomes 10%. But they've not been approved by the BPU yet. Of course, as you know, rate base growth is a good indicator of earnings growth, but then one has to add load growth and subtract O&M growth, and those are 2 parts that are tougher to predict . We've -- we do a good job of controlling O&M, but I would not want to promise that we will be able to control O&M at a level of 0, which is about where the load has been growing. It's like 0.1%, 0.2%. So it's -- suffice to say that the earnings growth will -- would probably be a net subtraction from that rate base growth, but we don't give an exact number of what that is.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Praful Mehta from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question is from Praful Mehta from Citigroup.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: So first question was on the separation, the generation separation side, the PEG Power side. I know we've talked about this before, but given how ICPs are trading today, it -- they really seem to struggle. And I was wondering in that market context, does
componenttext: So first question was on the separation, the generation separation side, the PEG Power side. I know we've talked about this before, but given how ICPs are trading today, it -- they really seem to struggle. And I was wondering in that market context, does it make sense to think about PEG  Power being separated? Or do you now reconsider and think more of keeping that PEG Power as part of the whole PSEG family?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Fred [ph]. I will not have a lot new to say about this subject. If we may, if and when or we were to make such a decision, it would not be a market timing decision. It would have to do with the strength of the strategic arguments in favor of separati
componenttext: Yes, Fred [ph]. I will not have a lot new to say about this subject. If we may, if and when or we were to make such a decision, it would not be a market timing decision. It would have to do with the strength of the strategic arguments in favor of separation dwarfing the tactical benefits that we continue to believe dominate the picture today in terms of staying together. So sure. You wouldn't try and do something in the middle of the economic instability or major macroeconomic disruptions, but we're not market timers. The real question is, do we still have the financial synergies between the businesses, do we still have to build synergy between the businesses, do we still have long term investors who see the attractiveness of both and those kind of strategic flexibility are questions that we've talked about before.

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then going ahead with the nuclear discussions that you were having earlier, there is obviously discussion in New York to support nuclear with -- through this next program. Do you see other states looking to implement something like this?
componenttext: Fair enough. And then going ahead with the nuclear discussions that you were having earlier, there is obviously discussion in New York to support nuclear with -- through this next program. Do you see other states looking to implement something like this? Or do you see that as a possibility from New Jersey or Pennsylvania in terms of support for nuclear or carbon-free generation?

headline: Public Service Enterprise Group Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 31, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do. I think that a lot of states are realizing that these are long-lived assets, these meaning nuclear plants, that provide enormous benefits, both from a carbon point of view, from a fuel diversity point of view, from a reliability point of view. And m
componenttext: I do. I think that a lot of states are realizing that these are long-lived assets, these meaning nuclear plants, that provide enormous benefits, both from a carbon point of view, from a fuel diversity point of view, from a reliability point of view. And most of our markets are fairly short term in nature. Even 3-year capacity prices don't capture the full benefit of what I expect to be a fairly expensive debate on how carbon's to be priced in the future. So they may -- every state may not come up with its own remedy, and regrettably, the right remedy would be a national remedy, but we don't seem to have a lot of traction in that regard right now. So I do see most of the action focused at the state-by-state level.
